Name: Robert Mawhinnie
Title: Five Stars
Reviews: Great low light lens. Photo was taken with a Nikon D7100

Name: MicahO
Title: Buy the Sigma USB Dock and Calibrate it First Thing or You'll be Sorry- *Updated*
Reviews: This is my new everything lens. I've got a 70D that I've been using on an off for a year. Recently I just lost my job and began picking up freelance work and I needed a much faster lens for the new work I was doing. I bought this baby and I love it. I'm able to get very good indoor low light shots and still keep a substantial amount of bokeh. It's got a great build quality and wonderful feel. I still haven't gotten used to the lens zoom which is opposite of Canon lenses but its a small problem I'm sure I'll soon adjust to.I'm sure you can find a million reviews on this lens out there better and more in-depth then mine but I thought I'd give my two cents. I've never broken away from buying Canon before and and there are many out there like my old self. If you are one of those people you can't ignore this beauty. It's a GREAT lens and you won't regret picking one up.*Update*:So a few weeks after writing this post I shot a friends wedding and I found that when taking pictures at around 20 feet or so away I had very soft focus. I learned that day there were a few sweet spots with this lens but the further I got from my subject the softer the focus got. I initially thought it was my 70D camera was at fault after reeding that they had an inherit flaw when shooting in apertures above 2.8. I learned later that this did turn out to be an issue with my camera (not all 70D's do this by the way but it's worth checking out if you're in the market for a fast lens). I decided to keep my aperture at a minimum of F2.8 but my images were still soft.I thought I'd always have issues and was contemplating selling the lens then I discovered that Canon recently came out with 80D and I wondered if this might fix my issues... it sadly did not (but don't get me wrong, the 80D did fix the inconsistent autofocus at shots greater then F2.8). I dug back into researching and found a docking device that Sigma sells that allows you to update the firmware of the lens from your computer. I dug a little deeper and found it also allows you to make micro adjustments to the auto focus.Now before you go out and pick on of these up ($60 by the way) let me tell you a few things. It takes FOREVER to micro-adjust your lens. There are a few video tutorials that tell you how to do it but let me tell you now, set aside about 4 hours or more and do it right. You'll need to buy a lens calibration alignment ruler (there is a paper one sold on Amazon for $6 that works fine) and get set up on a tripod with a computer near by. There are 16 adjustments that need to be made on this lens and each adjustment takes multiple times of undocking and redocking the lens from the computer. Also for the infinity shots, find something very very far away like mountains or a water tower you can focus on with good contrast. This one will be a bit more trial by error but do your best and you should get it pretty close to sharp.After multiple times of calibrating. taking a day to shoot, and recalibrating this lens now shoots AMAZING!!! It's like I have a new lens and it's finally trustworthy. It is razor sharp especially in the 2-10 foot range and the images that are coming out of this lens are down-right stunning.I moved my rating from a 5 at first (until I really got to know the lens) down to a 3 as a result of the year of uncertainty it put me through and wedding images I found to be sub-par (glad my buddy wasn't paying me and was fine with the quality otherwise I would of been furious). If you buy this lens buy the USB dock and a lens calibration ruler first thing and get it set right and you'll love this thing until the day you die. I'll add a photo of my dog that I just shot yesterday. This is what I'm getting at F1.8 from about 3 feet away.

Name: Maruwaan
Title: Sharp, Fast Aperture, Versatile Focal Length, Heavy!
Reviews: The Pros:This is an excellent lens with really good picutre and video quality. I took a few pictures and asked a few of my friends to guess the camera setup and nobody imagined it to be a crop sensor. The wide f1.8 aperture is awesome for bokeh and low light performance. Also the focal length basically covers 3 prime lenses! The zoom and focus rings are sleek with an overall build quality of a boss. This is the closest you'll get to full frame on a crop sensor body. It's crazy sharp!Now for the drawbacks.This lens is very heavy considering. I have the Canon 200d and 77d, and the lens almost feels heavier than both the cameras together. Make sure you have the correct tripod or Gorillapod if you plan to mount it. At times I'm even afraid to not hand cradle the lens as it just doesn't feel right with my hands on the camera body alone.Second is the focus motor, it's not the quietest and a tad slower than the canon stm lenses. In fact, its so loud that I can hear it even with my on camera Rode mic in auto focus. Just something to consider if you shooting an interview or a video where you require auto focus. Shoot in manual focus instead.Thirdly, lack of IS. Yep, no IS. Ultimately it's wide-ish focal length makes it acceptable.Lastly, this lens only works on crop sensor cameras. So for the price, many believe it to be a bit limiting. So weigh your options and decide if you willing to stick to crop sensor bodies.Conclusion:If you willing to deal with the drawbacks like I was, then it's an excellent lens. It's fast aperture with a versatile focal length makes it's almost impossible to pass up if you have a crop sensor camera.

Name: Dan M
Title: My second favorite lens for my Canon C100
Reviews: I love this lens. Love it, love it, love it.I own a Canon 24-105, 70-200, a Zeiss 50mm Makro, Sigma 30mm, previously owned a Canon 24-70, Tamron 24-70, and Tokina 11-17.This lens is amazing, built rock solid. Sharp as a prime, and wide enough that it doesn't look super distorted like my Tokina did when filming indoors.The zoom and focus ring are buttery smooth, just like my Zeiss prime.It works fantastic on my 550D as well.If you shoot video - this lens is honestly a must have. I do like my Zeiss more, as it is an amazing lens, but I use this one 10x as much due to the focal length.I wish it had IS - but hey, can't have everything.

Name: Gerard
Title: Sigma 70D
Reviews: I bought this lens mostly for my landscape photography mounted to my Canon 70D. Very impressed with this lens, heavy and I love it.

Name: W. Dyer
Title: Sharp at every focal length.
Reviews: A very sharp lens, with a very fast and usable large aperture, f 1.8. It is sharp at f1.8 and just gets sharper until f8 when diffraction begins to set in. It is still very usable at f16 for greater depth of field. It is sharp across the field of view, center to corner. It has the focal length equivalent on a full frame camera of 27mm to 52mm. Not a huge range, but a useful one. It is reported to be sharpest at 18mm but it is sharp at all focal lengths. It is a somewhat heavy lens, but very well built. It does not have vibration reduction. But it is very hand holdable in the 1/25 of a second to 1/100th of a second depending on focal length. Higher shutter speeds are of course better. Highly recommended for Nikon and Canon crop sensor cameras.

Name: Andrew P Sorensen
Title: As good as it gets!
Reviews: First off know what you're buying...but if you do, you won't be disappointed. This is by far the sharpest lens I've shot with. I plan on shooting with this far more extensively but wanted to say I'm impressed. This is not a "macro" lens but I used it to shoot small objects and got far more detail than I had expected.I'm posting a picture blown up to double so you can see some of the detail rendered. On a moth I could see every crease and wave on its wing.I knew this lens would be good, but I had no idea it would be this good.Beware and this isn't the lenses fault but if you're too close to an object this lens will focus on the closest spot it can. It seemed initially like it was misfocusing but it was human error. Most lenses will continue to hunt.Truly a phenomenal lens!

Name: Jason Garman
Title: Amazing image quality! Focus issues easily fixed via USB dock.
Reviews: This lens is astoundingly sharp! I'm using this with a Canon T6i and the resulting picture quality is nothing short of amazing. That said, you will most likely encounter focusing issues when shooting wide open. Then, why a 5 star review? As other reviewers have mentioned, don't buy this lens unless you also get the corresponding SIGMA USB dock for your camera mount.I have to say, at first, I was unhappy with the prospect of spending another $60 for the dock after dropping $900 for this lens. However, the truth is that any fast lens is going to require some level of microadjustment. And, let's be honest, what does Canon do in this situation? Send your body & lens off for "repair" to Canon, waiting weeks for them to return, with a chance of being damaged/lost in transit, and to top it off, no guarantee that the problem will actually be resolved to your satisfaction? I don't know about you but the savings in time and lost opportunity cost more than makes up the cost of the dock, and furthermore, I can ensure that the focus meets MY specifications. In my opinion, EVERY lens manufacturer should provide a way to microadjust their lenses in this way (at least until stupid body manufacturers like Canon don't provide a mechanism to do it in camera, shame on you!)Short answer, if you're looking for a great wide to normal zoom range lens for your crop sensor body, with image quality surpassing even the name brand prime lenses in this zoom range, you have to make the investment. You won't regret it.Swingset photo taken at f/2 @ 18mm, spin-a-letter photo was a focus test I took wide open at f/1.8 @ 28mm.

Name: Evie
Title: couldn't be more pleased!
Reviews: I would like to begin with stating that I am not a professional, there is so much that I still have to learn about photography. However, I decided to take a leap and make this purchase. First, I received the item three days sooner than expected and that made me super happy. I was impressed with the quick arrival of the product. Second, upon opening up the package and pulling out the lens I was impressed by the weight of it and the feel of it. Again I'd like to state that I am not a professional, however the item did not feel cheap by any means. It has a very solid feel. I's a complete amateur but I love, love, the effect that this specific lens give. I did only receive the lens and played with it for about an hour but still I am super excited to see what this thing can do, OH! yeah one thing that is noticeable is the AF feature, you can hear the lens trying to focus but the lens is pretty awesome I can live with it. Anyway, I will be updating my post after a couple months of use. Anyway hope that helps from an amateurs perspective.

Name: Engedalians
Title: I hated returning this
Reviews: Everything you've read about this lens is true. Most would call the end result "dreamy". I would call it sensuous. You can almost feel the captured scene. This lens is truly amazing, even more so that it's reasonably priced.I did find however that there are 3 issues with this lens only if you want to make video.1. It has some heavy breathing when in AF mode. I want to use AF since I'm mainly filming 3 small children running around. There is no way I could keep anything in focus using MF. This issue would not affect photography.2. The AF also makes a pretty disgusting noise that is audible within your video. This issue would not affect photography.3. This isn't the fault of the lens, but you cannot mount this lens on the Weebill Lab gimbal. It's just too dang big. You could use a larger gimbal but I really wanted to build a small kit so that I am not some crazy dad chasing his kids everywhere with some stabilizer contraption like this guy pictured below.I returned this lens and got the 12-35 2.8 II. This lens has native AF, power image stabilization and weather proofing. The image quality is superb. It's not "delicious", "dreamy" or "sensuous" but it's still probably the best lens for my needs.I may very well purchase this lens again later in life, but that would simply be for photography or video where the scenes are completely controlled.

Name: Randy W. Dietmeyer
Title: First lens where I actually noticed a significant difference!
Reviews: Without a doubt the sharpest lens I now own for my 7D Mark II. Putting this on actually made me feel like I upgraded the camera body itself! I just wish it had a wider zoom range and I am still swapping it for my 24-105 L.UpdateThere was a slight flaw on my copy which appeared like a slightly darker curved band on the left side of the photo. It is only visible in something like a bright sky shot and after adjusting the contrast. But it is in every such photo. Other than that the edge to edge detail was phenomenal. Hopefully my new one will be just as sharp minus the lens flaw. Here is a photo showing the slight dark curved band on the left.UpdateI did end up returning it and got a new copy of the lens in today. After a couple of test shots it is clear (pun intended) that this one does not have the slight dark band aberration that my first lens had.

Name: FastK5
Title: Amazingly sharp but very frustrating!
Reviews: The sigma 18-35mm is both sharp and frustrating to use. The autofocus is not reliable. But after making adjustments with the USB dock I could get it working well except when shooting objects at infinity with the focal length set to 35mm. I use the Pentax k3 which has a fine adjustment for autofocus. I have managed to more or less get it working at all focal lengths except 35mm (when the object is very far away).This lens is unbelievably sharp for a zoom lens. I have 35mm 2.4, 40mm 2.8, and 50mm 1.4 prime lenses, and it is as sharp or sharper than all these primes. It is amazing in low light too, and sharp at f-1.8. If only the autofocus was more reliable! Live view is always sharp, and that is why it is so frustrating.l will keep adjusting the autofocus to see if I can get it working at all focal lengths. I will update this review in due time.

Name: Lokiparts
Title: It's a Game Changer
Reviews: I love, love, love this lens. I am far from being a professional photographer, or videographer, but I would easily consider myself an advanced amateur. For a long time I have been making due with an old 50mm lens as my only real fast lens along with a hand full of slow entry-level zooms and pancake primes. I had been dying to get a fast wide prime, but I was having a hard time picking the perfect focal length. So when I found this lens and started researching it, it almost sounded too good to be true.Well let me tell you on a crop sensor camera, the hype is real. It is so sharp and just takes absolutely lovely images. I’ll admit it’s not perfect, it is fairly large and heavy, and can be a little slow to focus at times, but these small flaws are easily overlooked when it comes to the eye popping image quality this lens produces. Even wide open the images are super crisp. I also recently had the chance to use it for a video project, and it may just be my new favorite video lens too. Overall I just cannot recommend this lens enough. I am fully team Sigma at this point, and I am already saving up to get the 50-100mm F1.8 next.

Name: BS!
Title: Good Lens But Slow AF
Reviews: This is indeed a sharp lens. It is bulky (much larger than one would think). The colors are neutral and the images are hard to fault. Very good for indoor and outdoor shooting. Construction is sturdy even though it has lots of plastic parts. I didn't notice any bothersome distortions. For Sony cameras, it's actually a very good choice because it doesn't have any major color casts and is even on the less saturated side, so it minimizes various color casts inherent in Sony rendering when white balance isn't calibrated to a strict 6500K daylight setting.Its one major flaw is focus speed. For photography, it's pretty slow when shifting larger distances. But, the focus speed works out well for video. It's very quiet and moves smoothly. I think this lens was optimized for video. But then again, such a large lens for APSc sensors might not be good for moving about. It'll work fine on larger setups though.

Name: DJ
Title: Great but heavy
Reviews: Unheard of 1.8 zoom. Using with Sony a6600 which has IBIS. Would be nice if the lens had IS too. Len's AF not as fast as a6600's AF so it's a compromise in keeping up.I usually stop down to 2.8 anyways to keep faces in focus, so perhaps the extra stops to 1.8 are wasted.Downside is the weight to this lens. It's large for a 1.8 lens and it's dated (I think it was released in 2013). Would be nice if Sigma released an update with IS and Sony e-mount compatibility so we don't have to use the MC-11 adapter.

Name: William Elliott
Title: The best lens for crop sensor DSLR, period.
Reviews: I own two of these actually. One Nikon mount (review here) and another Canon mount (bought elsewhere). I attach these to my Lumix GH4 and GH5 cameras using Metabones Speed Boosters for video capture. They are nothing less than spectacular. I shoot in a lot of small doctors offices and cramped areas. I also use these for shooting interviews and find they have little to no distortion. They are a little on the big and heavy side, but the quality that they produce is stunning.

Name: Luis L.
Title: Bringing almost full-frame quality to APS-C photography
Reviews: One of the greatests lenses you can get, it is heavy to carry around, but the results are outstanding. Remember as with any new lens you get, there's a learning curve, so don't rush it in, this one has so many possibilities, and did I mention that it is fast? Having been handling lenses of all sorts for the past 3+ decades, I can assure that this one brings a lot excitement, and incredible pictures! Highly recommend for APS-C sensor formats.

Name: Michael
Title: Excellent
Reviews: I've been using this lens with my Nikon D7100 for over three years and I use it 95% of the time as I shoot mostly landscapes and it works well for portraits too at 30-35mm. This lens brings my Nikon crop sensor camera pretty close to full-frame quality. The only problem I have with using a non-Nikon lens is there's no in-camera auto correction for lens distortion, so I would have to buy Adobe Lightroom to correct for the distortion. I find Nikon's View NX2 software is excellent at post processing my RAW images so I really don't want to buy Lightroom just to fix the lens distortion. And if I do buy Lightroom I'll have to redo all my old RAW files that I've already processed with View NX2. But if you already have Lightroom then there's no reason not to get this lens as it's as good as it gets at a price that's a relative bargain.

Name: DJ Savage
Title: My favorite lens above all
Reviews: This lens is amazing and probably the best lens you will ever have, but it is only for cinematography. It is a Super clear lens Great for cinema but this is not a lens made for photography. The only thing I did not like about this lens is that it is a bit heavy but maybe that is the reason it is such a great lens, so I can live with that. You will have to add pull focus/zoom gears to this lens, not a deal breaker. If you’re serious about filming, this is your lens.

Name: Kamelle Jaye
Title: Sharp Fast Heavy
Reviews: This is my second favourite lens to use overall and my favourite lens to use for landscapes. I own a Canon 80D and I love how sharp my photos look. I'm not too technical when it comes to lens specs but as a casual photographer I usually have this and my 24-70 in my bag. I tried using it for portraits and I kept it at the 35mm focal length. (For me 18mm is a bit too wide for APS-C. I think its a 28mm Full Frame equivalent).The only downsides to this lens are its weight. It is a brick. There also is no image stabilization. Those 2 things dont affect me that much. I only notice the weight of the lens when I go on long hikes, but maybe I just need to get stronger.I love this lens and you won't be disappointed if you purchase this.

Name: Joshua
Title: El mejor lente que hay
Reviews: Desde hace mas de veinte años me dedico a la fotografía. He aprendido que en vez de invertir en cámaras hay que invertir en lentes. Pero los mejores lentes son muy costosos. Decidí vender tres de mis lentes. Nikon 35 mm 1.8 G; Nikon 50 mm 1.8 D y mi sigma 18-50 2.8. Y coloqué la diferencia. No me arrepiento. La calidad de lente es superior(algo pesado), trabaja en cualquier condición de luz y mi Nikon D7500 trabaja superbien. Cuando lo compré temí algún defecto de micro ajuste de enfoque. Pero este lente no tuvo ningún problema. De forma preventiva compré el dock. Repito la calidad de las imágenes es superior y disfruto aun mas haciendo mis trabajos de fotografía.

Name: DDuck4Life
Title: Nothing better on the market for what it does
Reviews: Fantastic lens. super sharp and has the potential to be my walk around lens. Great for anyone looking to shoot in low light situations and don't want to worry about have the correct prime lens for the situation. If you can find it in stock.the lens is able to focus very fast and with the HSM you can't hear a thing. while you can still hear the motor if everything is completely silent, if there is any background noise going on you won't hear a thing.Amazing for shooting video. the super quiet focusing motor means you won't hear the lens moving to gain focus while filming. Who wants to hear the focus motor running instead of the people in the shot while filming a scene, no worries with this lens.Fantastic for those low light shots where you still need a fast shutter.keep in mind this is not a small light lens. On the end of your camera this will add some size and weight if you are not used to shooting with lens of this size. It has replaced every prime in my kit between these focal lengths.There is a reason this lens is sold out everywhere. don't hesitate to buy this lens if it becomes available to you or just put your name on the waiting list.

Name: Tony
Title: Must have.
Reviews: You won’t regret buying this. Great for on the go. I like the weight of it. Feels like quality in your hand bc it is. Image quality speaks for itself. Being apsc, the long end (35) feels like 50 on FF which is perfect and the short end (18) is great for getting that wider shot of you might need in most situations. Having f1.8 all the way through is fantastic.This was the second copy I ordered, bc the focus ring on the first one was a bit weird. This second one is perfect though. Zoom and focus ring are insanely smooth. Love. This. Lens.

Name: Charles Le Pere
Title: Awesome companion lens to BMPCC6K
Reviews: I bought this primarily for video work with my BMPCC6K. It is a spectacularly sharp lens. The build quality is superb. I also have the Canon 17-55mm F/2.8 EF-S (not full frame lens). I definitely like the wider aperture of the sigma more and the fact that the sigma does not telescope through its zoom range, unlike the canon. But canon’s zoom range is greater and it has optical image stabilization, which I am miss greatly on the sigma. So I end up using the sigma for shoots with people using a tripod or stabilizer and the canon for landscape work typically.Again, I love this lens. I would definitely recommend it for video work! And if you’re deliberating between this or the canon, get this one if your primary subjects are people. Otherwise stick to the canon.

Name: clovisthecat
Title: Best zoom lens for aps-c
Reviews: I use this on my a6500 coupled with mc-11. sony when used with its native lenses produces a very digital-looking images. But when I put this sigma on, wow, im very surpised it produces images with full of life - similar on what i see with my 5dm4.Image quality is astonishing. Bokeh is great.Cons of using with mc-11 on sony- it keeps hunting for the right focus point and around 70% accurate at Night. Daytime has much better performance. For video work the lens is very noisy so i have a separate audio recording device.I can only wish that its zoom length is much further, has less weight, has snappier focus and has IS. but for its current price, im happy with it and this definitely a keeper

Name: Doug Davis
Title: Extremely Sharp even at 1.2! (1.2 with metabones adapter on the GH4)
Reviews: I recently got my Panasonic GH4 and was told this was the go to lens for most shooters with this camera. I did my research and found out this lens becomes a 1.2 with the metabones adapter.. I had to try it out. I purchased this used right here from amazon for a few hundred dollars cheaper and I couldn't tell that the lens wasn't brand new.. It came with not a single mark on it and worked as If nobody ever used it. I'm assuming someone returned it once they found out it was a cropped sensor and wouldn't work properly on a Full Frame Camera. Luckily for me, the GH4 isn't full framed and it worked and looks amazing.The lens is verrrrry sharp even wide open at 1.2 I was shocked! It doesn't have IS but that doesn't effect me because I use a glidecam or tripod, you'll only see a little shake while your filming hand held. It's also around 2 pounds in weight for those wondering.I purchased this for many reasons after countless hours of doing my research. Besides other people praising it.. This is also why I purchased:- Very sharp lens. I read that it is basically a few primes built into one lens. I'd have to agree as it looks great no matter what.- I could go to 1.2 with an adapter and that could help a ton in low light situations.- It has much more DOF compared to the panasonic 12-35 lens and can go to 1.2 instead of 2.8.- I needed help with the low light issue and the Panasonic 12-35 isn't good for low light while this can help me make up for ISO.- Panasonics 12-35 mark II is apparently coming out with the GH5 so I'll wait to see if it's worth the buy later.- Sigma Art lenses have always been worth the money. I've never met someone who has something bad to say about them.I shot an interview this morning for a local gym and had this on my GH4 the entire time. I'll Post a screenshot of the video (ungraded) for you to see.

Name: doesitmatter
Title: Abe's of Maine aka Abe's Electronic Center not Authorized Dealer.
Reviews: Read about Abe's online, bait and switch, underhanded sales techniques, etc. Called Nikon and asked about them, they verified Abe's is not an authorized Nikon dealer because of these tactics. They are also not on Sigma's list of authorized dealers and Sigma states on their website they will not honor the warranty if purchased from non-authorized seller. Sent back immediately without using.

Name: Riducharme12
Title: Should Be Your First Lens
Reviews: As someone who is just beginning to really get into film, I heard a lot of talk about this lens. I thought maybe, like most things on the internet including reviews, that it might be overhyped. I splurged though and was not disappointed. This lens is fantastic. It does everything you want and gives your film that medium/close up shot that really pops. No need to worry about if your kit glass (the lenses that most people buy with the camera) have enough depth of field to really convey what the subject is, this lens clearly emphasis it + so much bokeh! A great overall lens for film. Would recommend to anyone who wants to start to make their shots look cinematic and beautiful.

Name: Lee O.
Title: Automatic buy! . . . trust me!
Reviews: Before purchasing this lens, I decided to rent it for a couple of days and see how well it performed. I used it to take photos for a local late night talk show and it left me very impressed.As many reviews on the internet and youtube might tell you, this lens is super sharp. I never thought I would want to take photos at the widest aperture of f/1.8 but I was so enthralled at how sharp it was wide open. It was matched up to my Canon 70D and it performed well past my expectations. Previously I was stuck with using my Canon 17-55mm f/2.8, which is still a very good lens, but this Sigma trumps any photo I've taken when it comes to clarity, contrast, and sharpness.The only true gripes I might have about this lens, is the short focal range and the speed of the auto focus. My Canon 70D has an APS-C crop sensor, making the 18-35mm range more in lines with 28-56mm (1.6x crop factor). That's still a good focal range for landscape and portrait photography, but too short to use at something like a concert or for sports. The autofocus is super smooth and very quite, but the focus is a little slow compared to my Canon 17-55mm f/2.8. Not that big of a gripe, but when you're trying to capture a moment, every millisecond counts. Also, it doesn't have image stabilization like my Canon, so videography would be a little bit more difficult unless you had a glide or camera stabilizer of some sort.All in all, I made the purchase and I couldn't be happier. Sigma made a believer out of me and I'll continue to purchase from them as long as the quality and performance is there. If you have a crop sensor camera, don't hesitate. Buy this lens pronto!

Name: Andrew
Title: Focus is off sometimes
Reviews: Great lens. Only issue I have is the focus on it. Usually when I'm zoomed alllll the way out it may not focus the best. I took some pictures and couldn't tell on my camera that I was out of focus even though my focus point was where it should've been. This can be a big deal if you're getting paid for your photography or videography.

Name: David F.
Title: Best auto-focus lens I've ever had!
Reviews: There are a boatload of reviews about this lens on youTube so, if you want something detailed, go there. This lens is AWESOME! It takes zero effort to shoot good photos with this thing, even on a D3200!!!!! I can't wait until the 50mm-100mm is released so I can buy that and complete my lens collection!Update 4/1/2016 - I wanted to update this comment with some actual photos of the lens. I have yet to gain skills to properly review it from a technical point of view but would rather let these quick photos speak for themselves. Just a few I snapped, one of which while driving without even looking at the camera!

Name: Tommy D
Title: Awesome
Reviews: This lens turned out to be heavier than I thought it would be, but definitely not problematic. I like the solid feel it has on the Nikon D500, and even on an older D7100. One of the reasons I went with all Sigma lenses was because of problems with auto-focus. Sigma gives me the option (with the USB dock) of adjusting any back or front focusing issues. I prefer this over trying to go through the incomplete effort of changing the focus issues in the camera.

Name: Nick S.
Title: Beauty and the beast! All in one.
Reviews: Yes, it's big but if you want it for it can do there's no way around it that I know of.I did not want the f/1.8 just for its light gathering capability (although it doesn't hurt to have it) but more for the narrow depth of field it allows. For "environmental" portraits (i.e. not just a head shot but also including a good deal of the background for context) with that "full frame" look I don't think that there's a more versatile lens for APS-C cameras. Add in the fact that it's just about as sharp (if not sharper) than similar prime lenses and you've got a winner.Update: I forgot to mention that the build of the lens is great. I have some other EX DG Sigma lenses which were well built but this is a notch above those. The materials look like high quality, both the focus and zoom rings move smoothly and without any wobble.

Name: Ike
Title: Autofocus  nightmare.
Reviews: This is the sharpest POS I've ever seen would be a great lens has very high ratings I cant figure out why. The lens itself is great glass and great quality the auto focus is so bad ... you have to buy the docking station update if available. Mine is already up to date I have to program and change the auto focus at every focal length. NOT EASY. Lens made me want to pull my kit lens out of the closet.

Name: Benjamin Anderson
Title: Best Investment Ever
Reviews: I never write reviews. Today I am. Received mine today and this is the only lens I will ever need again. I was hoping to get my money's worth and I did. Right out of the box, everything I'm shooting looks amazing. The bouquet is stunning. Focusing issues that I've read about? I bought the dock and haven't fine-tuned anything yet and am not sure if I'll need to - I have no complaints. I bought this lens for video after seeing some excellent cinematic-quality footage and I was able to recreate that look within hours. Unbelievable quality. Save yourself some money - this lens is at least 3 primes in one. Amazing in low light too.

Name: ThatCarGuyEddie
Title: Perfect Glass. Fell in love.
Reviews: I purchased this lens used from 6ave for $629 shipped. It was said to be in "like new" condition, and it was. I was very pleased with the condition it came in. Now for the photography side of this review. The low light capabilities of this lens is amazing. Additionally this lens is great for almost anything else, unless you need to shoot a far distance shot (which I never do). I'll include some of my most recent shots with this lens. Finally I would definitely recommend this to all my friends.

Name: TRJ
Title: Sharp as a tack. These feel heavy and sturdy, but they're not. Read review
Reviews: The actual barrel that the mount base (stainless steel) mounts to is an engineering plastic. So even though it feels and looks all-metal, it's not. And an important piece is breakable plastic inside. The lens will separate from the mount if any hit is taken by the lens and that in-turn tears the flex cables, making a repair an expensive proposition. All in all though, it goes head to head with L-glass for sharpness, bokeh and light gathering. Wish it were a bit more of a range as 18-35 is pretty damn limiting at times.

Name: A. Tolman
Title: solid lens
Reviews: This is a large, serious piece of glass. It takes sharp, colorful pictures and, in all the venues I've used it, focuses briskly and reliably. There are times when I wish for a bit more zoom range, but the speed of the lens and the quality of the pictures means that they're croppable without loss of quality. Works very well on my D7100.

Name: Kara Heinrich
Title: Did not fit e-mount
Reviews: I was so excited when I saw they added Sony to the compatibility lineup for this lens. Did 3-4 days of research on this lens before biting the bullet and purchasing it. I did not find a clear answer as to whether or not it was for e-mount or a-mount, but after reading multiple articles and watching reviews on YouTubers being excited for the e-mount launch I decided to purchase. When I received the lens it was heavy and beautiful, I immediately went to try on the lens only to discover that it was too big for for the emount. I called sigma and they let me know that anything that just says Sony is an a-mount lens. I did not want to purchase an a-mount converter on top of the lens, so I ended up returning. Disappointed because I was so excited to try out this lens.

Name: Richard
Title: amazing lens but it’s an APS-C
Reviews: only reason i give it 4 stars is because my sony a6000 with an adapter over shoots the focus a lot and i have to sit and wait for it to adjust multiple times. other than that. one of the best lenses i’ll own. sigma is one of the best retailers for glass. image quality is sharp and crisp per usual from Sigma’s Art series.only downfall is it’s built for aps-c which means it’ll vignette like crazy on a full frame if and when i upgrade to a full frame.

Name: Nate in Florida
Title: Just about perfect
Reviews: love this lens, absolutely love it. I have been wanting to get away from the standard low end kit lenses ever since I started photography about 15 years ago, now all I want to do is throw those old lenses away after getting my hands on this. The focus is lightning fast, the auto focus when shooting video is flawless and nobody is going to say anything bad about the f/1.8 at EVERY focal length. I'm taking pictures now that would have been impossible for me before.

Name: Michelet Díez Posada
Title: Finally bought the best APSC lens for video!
Reviews: I mainly bought this lens for video for my 80D, works perfectly, it is HEAVY know that, is not a "walk around take pictures with" lens.The sharpness is just another level, the focus speed is just right and gotta say is not as loud as many people has said.This lens DOES NOT have image stabilization, so have that in mind, you need a gimbal or have very steady hands.

Name: Julia
Title: Want to improve your video for YouTube? THIS IS IT!!❤️
Reviews: I LOOOVE this lens so much! Been wanting this for so long and finally my hubby gifted it to me for Christmas😀 I have a beauty YouTube channel, and I’ve been wanting to get that blurred background as others YouTube’s have, and I got it! Highly recommend this lens if you want to improve your video quality, trust me, your viewers will appreciate that 🔥🔥 This lens is pretty heavy, like HEAVYY:) Took me sometime to get used to that, as well as I had to use a more sturdy stand holder for my Canon M50, but that’s okay☺️ Thanks Sigma for creating such beauty ❤️❤️

Name: Working Man
Title: Get this lens!
Reviews: Words can not express how happy I am to own this amazing lens! It has a very usable range and it goes to F1.8!The lens if very sharp wide open, very little to almost not noticeable CA and vignette. The build quality is very solid, the lens has some weight to it, not to mention it's solid focus along with comfortably dampened zoom and focus rings.I bought this for my Canon 650D which pushes this camera to it's limits! I look forward to more shots with this amazing lens!

Name: ColoCultureMedia
Title: If you are thinking about it, just buy it.
Reviews: If you are making Youtube videos or any videos. Buy this. There is tons of evidence that this is a great lens on Youtube. I use this with a 70D to make YT videos and with a Lumix G85. Yea it is heavy but no matter what you are shooting it is going to be crisp. The only other lens I use is a 10-18 when needing a super wide angle. This is a bokeh monster. I've even used it to vlog. Willzworldmedia on youtube for more visuals in 4k.

Name: Amazon Customer
Title: Simply Amazing!!
Reviews: I film short instagram videos and longer YouTube videos. Before i got this lens i was using a 50mm 1.8 stm gor canon. Which was great but i needed alot of space to film which I don’t have so i have to do the filming in a friends house. This lens got delivered from korea in 2 friggn days!! Super sharp, quick AF, not as heavy as exaggerated on YouTube reviews, everything is perfect ❤️❤️👏🏾👏🏾. Best lens for videographers!!

Name: Tamora
Title: Highly recommended!
Reviews: I rented this first to test it out and was blown away by the photos I was getting on my Canon 70D then purchased it immediately. Forget carry a bunch of lenses around. This is basically a bunch of primes in one. I ended up selling my 2 kit lenses, 40mm STM and 50mm f1.8 as this lens replaced them all. Just add good zoom lens to your arsenal and you have everything you need to take awesome photos!

Name: D. Liu
Title: I love this lens
Reviews: I love this lens. I use it for all my vacation travels and don't even use my walk around lens anymore. It's super clear and the contrast is good. It's so fast that it's great for low light.This is basically permanently affixed to my canon 60d when i go anywhere. Indoors low light, it helps capture a small room, outdoor and sunny and it's great for capturing landscapes or buildings.I'm debating on buying a canon 5m mirrorless when it comes out and an adapter, instead of moving to another brand because this lens, I really don't want to give it up.

Name: Edgar Campos
Title: Pretty Good!
Reviews: Not the best for portrait photography, but it's solid for cameras that arent full frame! The autofocus is great! Video wise this is the lens to go. Photos, it could be better.

Name: B. Tran
Title: Great lens for Canon 70d
Reviews: I've been wanting this lens for a long time and was not disappointed when received. I can't believe how sharp the pictures are and the nice bokah it provides. Do note that you want to do a focusing test and adjustment because I heard that these lens may need them, so if you get it and it is front/rear focusing do the adjustments or send it in with your camera body to get adjusted. Once it is adjusted for your camera you will be amazed how the pictures look.

Name: Amazon Customer
Title: The constant aperture and the lens' clarity are phenomenal. ...
Reviews: The constant aperture and the lens' clarity are phenomenal. The only two drawbacks are the focal length and lack of image stabilization, but the lack of these features is well worth the price point — especially if you do a lot of model or concert photography and have steady hands. At f/1.8, image stabilization isn't a problem because it brings in a lot of light; either way, find a way to keep your shutter speed above 1/200 and stability shouldn't be a problem.

Name: wile-e-coyote
Title: 2 months in this is my go to lens
Reviews: Buying used is a great way to save some money and in this case I didn't sacrifice a shred of quality. This is the lens that is on my camera the most. It's super sharp and I love the fact that I get a very shallow depth of field (f1.8) in a zoom. This is much better than the nifty 50 for apsc cameras. The only downside, if you consider it one is the lens has some heft to it, but it's also a mark of the quality that went into it.

Name: Joelrunner
Title: Prime quality with the flexibility of adjustable lenses!
Reviews: I had a 50mm prime f1.4 lens, and a 17-55mm f2.8 lens stolen out of my car. I loved (and needed) them both, and was not looking forward to the cost of replacing them... I was hesitant that this lens would replace them both, but I actually like it BETTER due to the flexibility it has.I don't miss either of my old lenses at all now that I have this.

Name: Lester
Title: Amazing lens for glidecam/steadycam work.
Reviews: Man, I cannot praise this lense enough. It is just such a great zoom range for most things, and especially for video production. This thing is amazing on a steadicam/glidecam. The balance barely gets thrown off when zooming and is easy to correct. The ability to open to 1.8 is such an amazing help. While filming a wedding I was so glad to have this fast of a lens and for such a great price.Pros:Sharp!Internal zoomSolid as a rock!Very fast.Little to no lens flaresCons:Not a big fan of the end cap. Doesn't go on very easily.Some may say the price, but I think the price is justifiedNo Vibration compensation

Name: ashley rippeon
Title: Heavy.  But manageable
Reviews: Pretty heavy. Takes great pics. Works best at at a smaller fstop like 2.2 or “higher”. Does a great job at lifestyle photography as well as portrait. I don’t seem to get too much distortion up close. My number one lens at the moment.

Name: N. Zahrani
Title: not professional photographer
Reviews: I'm not professional photographer so this review is from someone who wants a blurry background in a medium sized room (3.5 mt/ 11.4 ft) for YT videos the easy way with minimal fuss- and this lens does jus that and Im happy with it. It's heavy but my gorillapod works fine with it.

Name: waterdog
Title: Warm this puppy before entering humid environments... but put this in your bag, it's an Excellent lens.
Reviews: Great lens, will not repeat everything that's been written about it. Much less focusing issues with this lens with my Cannon 70D than my Cannon lens, especially the 50mm. Really surprising and odd. Did have condensation develop INSIDE lens itself when exposed to humid air from cool building. Condensation is a given in this situation but never had it form inside the lens, after 15-20 minutes was still inside lens. After 1/2 hr indoors it cleared. Concerned that moisture could get trapped inside and need servicing. Will make sure to warm this lens in similar conditions.Still this is a 5 star lens, such a solid build and great images. Knowing what I know now will pre warm humid environments.

Name: M
Title: My new all purpose lens, but adding a 90D.
Reviews: Found this lens at the last minute, to shoot a wedding with my old Canon 60D. It’s amazing! Hand held shots during Mass, 800 ISO at f3.2 and sharp as can be. Used the 18-35 for 95% of my event.👍

Name: Ernesto García
Title: Great lens for wide-angle wide-aperture needs, fully recommended
Reviews: I'm an amateur photographer, and as such, I appreciate the versatility that this lens gives me. First, the wide aperture at a wide angle, something that is hard to find even on primes, and second, the fact that is not a prime lens and allows you a certain degree on zooming, albeit not much. but who would ask for more of this.Ok, but if you're on this page you already know what's the appeal of this lens, you just want to know if it's worth it. My verdict is: it is worth it. The build quality is great, as is its visual appearance. It's a professional-looking lens. And the feel in your hands is amazing. The zoom and focus rings are smooth to handle, and with a very nice grip thanks to the rubberized surface. The image quality is very nice, comparable to prime lenses they say. I don't have enough experience to say it myself, but I can say the image quality is superb. It's sharp, and the bokeh at f1.8 is really nice. That was one of the reasons I wanted a wide aperture lens, the other being shooting in low light conditions, which I already did and was amazing. A friend saw my pictures and thought I had taken a tripod with me to achieve the level of exposure I got from a night landscape.My only reservation when buying it was the fact that there are some worrying reviews out there of people that has had the bad luck to get a copy of this lens that presents some issues with auto-focus. Fortunately that was not my case, but I certainly wouldn't dismiss those concerns. If you can, buy this at store where you can try the exact lens you'll be taking home. In any case, this issue appears to be uncommon.Finally, only buy this lens (or any lens for that matter) if you know it provides the features you look for the most in your photography endeavors. If you shoot mostly at a wide angle setting, and you're craving for more aperture, this lens is for you. Even more so if you're a crop-sensor person (this lens is crop-sensor specific) and you're not planning to go full-frame anytime soon. Also consider some possible inconveniences of the lens before purchasing it, like the fact that is not small, and is not lightweight.

Name: John Lehmann
Title: Love it!
Reviews: I was looking at buying several prime lenses and started reviewing this as an option. I am super happy I did. The lens is super fast, has better color capture and a great improvement over the kit lens. The only thing is that it is heavy. But that being said you can definitely tell it is well made.

Name: Arjun Amisagadda
Title: I have heard that this was a nice lens, but my specific models focus ring was ...
Reviews: I have heard that this was a nice lens, but my specific models focus ring was malfunctioning. At one time it was smooth with quite a bit of tension, but after using the AF in my camera, if I had switched to manual focus, then the focus ring was not that responsive. I don't think that this is necessarily a bad lens, but I think I got a defective product. (using a Canon​ 80D)

Name: David Alexander
Title: Best for landscape, not portrait
Reviews: Excellent lens overall, I used it at the Grand Canyon for stunning photos. Not great in low light situations. Meh for portrait. Good depth of field, nice and wide for landscapes. I used it in 16:9 photos, and the daylight photos turned out really nicely.

Name: David Atherton
Title: Incredible lens!!
Reviews: Pros: 1. Constant f/1.8 is so nice to have on a variable zoom lens. 2. The build quality in incredible, especially for this price point. 3. Very little chromatic aberration! (Was very impressed) 4. Relatively fast and accurate autofocus with Videography 5. Smooth and quiet ring operation with an impressively long focus throwCons: 1. For crop sensor cameras. 2. Loud auto focus (with sometimes it missing the focus in photography)Overall an absolute must buy lens! I highly recommend it.

Name: me
Title: ... 6 months now and feel I can give a useful review. The first thing is this is a ...
Reviews: I have had this lens for 6 months now and feel I can give a useful review. The first thing is this is a large and heavy lens. I carried it on a k3ii at the state fair for a full day and was always aware that it was there. This is not a lens that I can "forget" is there. Only my 60-250 f4 is larger and heavier. One thing that helps though is that it does not extend when zoomed. Some have complained that the lens cap is difficult to put on and does not stay on well; I find it takes a little more attention when installing but is not that difficult and stays on as well as any other I have. The lens shade is a nice small diameter, unlike the monster on the 12-24 f4, which makes it nicer when in the backpack and not on the camera. Focus is a real issue with this lens and many have given up on it for that reason, though some seem to get a reasonably good one out of the box. Mine was OK at all focal lengths except 35mm which I fixed with a -5 setting at that length with the dock. Now it focuses as well as any lens I have. Sharpness is very good but at 35mm my FA 35 f2 is just as sharp except wide open. I have used this lens indoors without a flash but you must remember that at large f-stops the depth of field is VERY shallow and focus must be spot on to get sharp results. Focus is fast and quiet and it does not hunt. There is some flair under certain conditions but this must be expected with 17 lens elements and so much glass.The build quality is equal to any Pentax lens I have. With the limited zoom range and size and weight that cannot be ignored I consider this lens somewhat of a niche lens; too limited to be a do all walk around lens but uniquely useful for certain applications and I am very glad to own it.

Name: Jaime E. Ortiz
Title: Versatility
Reviews: Initially, I tested this lens with my Canon EOS SL2 and worked great! I still need testing it with other cameras, like the Canon M50 and the Sony A7III with Sigma MC-11 adapter, so I will update, but I love it! Very nice pictures out of it!

Name: GenVicious
Title: Best prime/zoom lens ever!
Reviews: I have used a wide range and variety of lenses. This is by far one of the best and more superior lenses that I have ever used. I used to be a big supporter of 50mm f/1.4 lenses, don't get me wrong I still use my sigma 50mm, but the investment on this lens is worth EVERY penny. I'm big on videography and shoot in a lot of lowlight settings. All I have to say is, if you are big on landscape or even portrait photography, this is the lens to invest on. You won't have to upgrade for a long time. This lens heavily outweighs the use of my 50mm. I've never had a problem with any sigma lenses. I was also thinking of getting the 17-50mm f/2.8, but my room mate has one and this lens I have to say still out shines it's performance. If i could give this lens a 10/5 I would, but 5/5 should do. Hope this review finds yous well.

Name: Claire
Title: Great lens; Ridiculous hours spent to adjust focus issues
Reviews: Alright so, I like this lens. I really do. AFTER I got it to focus correctly. That is the main reason for star deductions; the time consumption that was put into get this lens to focus was completely ridiculous. And I know its still not focusing crystal clear like I would like but after several hours of constantly taking pictures and adjusting settings use the sigma dock, I finally stopped when I got to a point where I was content with how the pictures were coming out.

Name: Hemifam
Title: The Money Lens!
Reviews: This lens is absolutely amazing and guaranteed to make your photos and videos crispy. It has an extremely fast and quiet auto focus, it also fits perfectly in my camera bag. I highly recommend this lens to anyone that shoots photography or films videos for YouTube. You surely won’t regret purchasing this lens.

Name: spl42
Title: One of the best lenses out there
Reviews: So far this lens has been everything I've been dreaming about for past two years. Image is Sharp, the build quality is top notch it's really solid I'd say about a pound and half of weight. Just well made, great image. I use this strictly for video. If you're looking to take your filming to next level and maybe like me you can't afford a $2,000-$3,000 camera this lens will help.

Name: Eric
Title: Best Available Lens For Night And Indoor
Reviews: Using this lens for indoor, street, night portrait and day portrait photography is fantastic. You can get a pretty wide panorama at 28mm equiv. if you need it, and 50mm equiv. with incredible brightness and bokeh for portraits. The AF is lightning fast in all but the darkest scenarios and it's nearly silent. The lens is a bit heavy but clearly well built and easy to use, with the focus rings gliding effortlessly. Have used for personal nighttime shoots and professional nighttime and indoor shoots, and the quality is incredible even paired with a simple Canon T3i.

Name: Erick Bonilla López
Title: Amazing lens. Best lens for crop frame camera's
Reviews: I looooooove it. Amazing lens. Best lens for crop frame camera's. I recommend it.

Name: Trinh Dennis
Title: BEST OPEN APERATURE ZOOM LENS.
Reviews: Purchased this to fit on my Canon EOS m50 with a Canon EF - EF-M lens adapter. Produces pretty sharp images around f/2, unfortunately the autofocusing on this lens makes a little noise and the in body microphone in the Canon EOS m50 would pick up the sound. But other than that, perfect portrait lens.

Name: BlueBomberTurbo
Title: 5 Stars Isn't Enough! (EDIT:  3 Stars Until Replacement; See Review)
Reviews: ************************UPDATES AT END************************Used on a Sony A6000 + LA-EA2 adapter.I always have reservations about buying something that's so highly regarded, since usually the hype never matches the reality, or my expectations. This is one of the rare occasions that it does, and even surpasses it. This is the sharpest normal zoom lens I've ever used. And I've used the Nikon 17-55mm F/2.8, Tamron 17-50mm F/2.8, and Nikon 24-70mm F/2.8. Wide open, it's as sharp as or sharper than some high quality primes! The contrast kicks in around F/2.8, but that's not to say the lens is hazy at wider apertures. It's perfectly usable, and stopping down only makes things even more impressive. I took this lens to the New York International Auto Show two days after I got it, and when you're not in pixel peeping mode, it's hard to tell which images are shot at F/1.8 vs F/5.6, besides the out of focus areas.The fit and finish on this lens is top notch, even though it's only made of plastic. The lens is a bit hefty, but you'll see that in most top tier fast zooms, and nothing is faster than this one. The zoom ring is nicely weighted, and the focus ring doesn't stick or feel loose while manually focusing like some modern lenses can. The AF/MF switch is in just the right place when holding the camera, and has a positive click. The AF is also quick and nearly silent (only the photographer would hear it) for photo use. A bit noisy for video with the camera's built-in mic, so you'll want to use an external mic instead.In the end, if you're thinking about getting this lens, the only question on your mind should be "is 35mm long enough for me?" As far as anything else in the equation, Sigma has you covered better than anyone else. If 35mm is long enough, there's no reason to hold off on this lens. If not, go out and get this lens and a 50mm prime! ;)PS: I'd HIGHLY recommend getting the Sigma USB Dock with this lens, at only $60 extra. All zooms are known to be a bit off on focus on one end or the other to varying extents. Initially, mine was mostly off at 18 and 24mm, while 35mm was nearly perfect. After calibration, this lens is spot on, tack sharp, every time. Not only do you get the best normal zoom available, it can also be your most consistently accurate autofocus lens, too!************************UPDATE 5/8/15I've been having some serious AF consistency issues with this lens. With static subjects, is as good as your average lens in locking accurately, but with moving subjects, it's a whole different story. The lens tends to lock in front of or behind the subject at least 1/3 of the time. Of course, you can't expect accurate focusing 100% of the time with phase detection, especially when shooting wide open at F/1.8, but the amount that the focus is off is more than just an inch or two, even when stopped down. On a large percentage of shots, the lens will lock onto the background of the image, whether it be a wall or another person standing behind the subject, even if the focus point isn't even in the neighborhood of the background.I purchased the Sigma USB Dock for Sony A-mount lenses (not available on Amazon at the time) when I initially purchased this lens, and calibrated it so focus was spot on. Took a few hours to complete, due to the multiple focal lengths vs calibrating a prime. But all of that work did nothing to improve the accuracy on moving subjects. I learned that the hard when when I shot an event the weekend after receiving the lens. Whether it was broad daylight or very dim overhead lighting, the inconsistency was consistent. I spent a few weeks after that refining the calibration, but nothing has changed.Temporarily moving the rating down to 3 stars, as the optics are still incredible (the in-focus photos at the above event were outstanding!), but without reliable AF, the lens isn't useful for what it excels at: events, especially in low light. I'm sending the lens back to Amazon for a replacement, which will hopefully have proper AF ability.************************

Name: Bill
Title: Great lens
Reviews: Very sharp across the frame even at f1.8. f4 is sharp corner to corner. Only downside is the seller I received this from sent an international version with NO WARRANTY. Be aware If you see them going for around $639 you may receive the same.

Name: Eleftherios Kritikakis
Title: ONLY for specific uses at f/1.8-2.4 of course, heavy
Reviews: UPDATE: Though I returned this lens because pics were way too flat even for a zoom (depth rendition), I rented a copy to run more extensive tests. It's a little more flat than other zooms at this range, though it's probably the sharpest one in the center of the image, but so marginally you can't really spot much difference.Zooms are inferior to primes in depth rendition anyway, but some manufacturers are trying to combat this (Nikon), others are indifferent as long as the price is right (Canon), others are trying to do everything at once (Tamron).I'm not sure that one would prefer this over what Tamron and Nikon have to offer at the same focal length, but sharpness, yes, it's excellent in most of the image. Geometry it excellent too. But it's also insanely flat, as if one is taking the pic with a telephoto from far away - strong compression that shouldn't exist in this focal range.

Name: Adrian costa
Title: great quality, but TOO HEAVY
Reviews: the lens has very good construction quality, the photos are great, the 1.8 blur is fascinating.The bad thing is the weight and it usually has focus problems in some cameras. In my d5500 it was a headache to get the focus right, not so in the d7500

Name: KieuLy Nguyen
Title: Amazing quality for the price. Slow and audible auto-focus, though
Reviews: I've been using this for 3 months now. The photos are incredibly sharp. I have to say however that this lens doesn't have image stabilization but I knew it when I bought the item. That's easily fixable with a rig. What I do find as a small pet peeve is that the lens is slow to auto-focus and makes sound that is clearly audible when I take videos. It's a small fault in the lens and, for the price, I think this is the greatest aperture and length for those starting out in film making and want an all-rounder.

Name: Raj
Title: Doesn't Focus - Not compatible with canon 60D
Reviews: The lens is not compatible with 60D as is mentioned in the description. It does not focus and is not what i was expecting from all the reviews that are here.

Name: tman5890
Title: Best lens I've ever owned
Reviews: This is the best built, best performing, and best looking lens I've ever owned. I saved up months to purchase this item and I'm so glad that I did. The pictures are amazing and the aperture is fantastic for bokeh. The only downsides are the zoom, if it had a larger zoom I'd say this would be the only lens I needed. I have tried it in low lighting, but have not tried it out for stargazing shots. I plan on taking more pictures with this lens soon and I will update my review with what I find. So far I would say this lens is a must buy!

Name: Murdock
Title: Great lens, shipped without a lens cap
Reviews: The lens is great! Good build quality and really sharp. I’m using it with an adapter on my Sony a6500, so I’m not sure if I’m getting the full potential of the autofocus, but it’s a great lens for an amazing price.Only one issue, I bought it used, and it was in fantastic condition, but it didn’t come with a lens cap. Other than that, it’s a fantastic lens for the price.

Name: Lyndsey K. Hinsley
Title: The Fastest and Sharpest Zoom Lens Ever Made!
Reviews: This lens was released in 2013 and it wasn't until 2016 that I finally purchased it. It's 2019 and this lens still holds in own as the fastest and sharpest zoom lens ever made. The focus and zoom rings are smooth as butter with a comforting resistance for video/cinema applications. Wide open, at f/1.8, there is almost no chromatic abberation or vignetting. It's simply my favorite lens of all time.

Name: Kelvin Burnside
Title: Everything is excelent and fits my expectations but... There was no USB Dock on the box
Reviews: No USB Calibration Dock as described

Name: Mike Mutzel, MS
Title: Amazing Colors and Depth of Field--Highly Recommended
Reviews: This lens is absolutely amazing. I use it primary for family photos, cooking images and video interviews. It brings out vibrant colors, textures and depth of field that I've never been able to achieve before.It's worth every penny!

Name: TECHFIT360
Title: I love this Lens, it really has taken me to the next level in photography & videography!
Reviews: Where do i begin? Before i began making youtube videos i would always hear nothing but great things about the Sigma 18-35mm F1.8. Well i recently purchased this for myself and all i can say is OMG! This lens is incredible i mean where else can you find a zoom lens that has a 1.8 F-stop. This lens lets an insane amount of light in so i can keep my iso setting pretty low when shooting inside. My video quality has left the back of the line and straight to the front. I'm talking "Team Crispy" You see up to this point i had been using my 18-55mm Kit lens. So i was blown away by the quality of this lens and how heavy and well made it is. The zoom ring is amazing, i get nice fluid zoom action with the Lens. I am a very happy customer and you will be too. It comes with it's own hood and a very attractive carrying bag for the lens. If i could give this 10 stars i would. The only negative thing i can say is that sometimes the focusing can be a pain, but i am very satisfied with my purchase. So to those out there who want to take their photography and videography to the next level, then this lens is for you! I hope this review helps you with your purchasing decision.

Name: c3h8
Title: My preferred lense
Reviews: Very nice images along the entire range. F/1.8 is very shallow, I typically stop to F/2.8, but no issues anywhere along the spectrum.

Name: Piueti Maka

Name: Zachary J. Millimet
Title: Super Versatility with F1.8 Fixed Across a Critical Focal Range - Awesome Lens!
Reviews: I did a painstaking amount of research prior to purchasing this lens back in December 2013. IAt the time, I was looking to upgrade from the mediocre kit lens that came with my Canon T3i and I went back and forth between this lens, a litany of Canon L lenses, as well as considering just buying 2 separate prime lenses. At the end of the day, I don't think I could have gone wrong with any of my choices. It's hard to go wrong with high end Primes and Canon's L series lenses at the lower focal lengths are fantastic. So why did I buy the Sigma. Certainly, the reviews from professionals were all stellar. This gave me peace of mind Second, I spent a lot of time considering how I like to shoot. I really dislike using flash, bur rather prefer fast lenses with low F-stops to allow me to shoot indoors and in low light situations without flash, when possible. So the fact that this lens allows F/1.8 was a big selling feature. The fact that it was fixed across all the focal lengths really started to sell me. Lastly, this lens covers a small, but critical zoom range: 18-35mm. Especially because I shoot on a cropped body camera, this is the range I mostly live in all the time when shooting. This lens is perfect - functing like a prime, across a critical focal range. Some people have noted that it can be a bit soft on autofocus or mis-focus when using certain camera bodies. I choice my focal points very specifically, and this has not been an issues for me. The bokeh is very good, some lenses are better, but still this lens produces great bokeh. It is also a very large and heavy lens - there is a lot of glass here. Any prospective buyer should be aware of this. For me, I have come to appreciate this heft of the lens - it is part of what I love about this lens.

Name: McMeekin
Title: Bad copy? Returned and disappointed.
Reviews: USED ON A CANON t2i CROP SENSOR CAMERA BODY!Wide open there was more than just vignetting around the edges. The entire shot went very dark. The second problem and even more bothersome was the change in the amount of light let in at different focal lengths. The difference is so so so much that any time I zoom in or out, I have to change exposure compensation. To get the same exposure as Canon 16-35, or Canon 50mm 1.8, or kit lens 18-55, I had to set my exposure compensation to +5. What! +5! Any time I have had to adjust to +3 on any other lens I am almost blowing the entire photo out. I had to set +5 just to get the regular amount of light. So when I changed zoom I would have to adjust the other way... all the way down to -6. Is this real life!?PROS:Sharp sharp sharp!Great build qualityAlmost silent auto focusFast fast focus in my opinionI did not have focus problems just throwing this right on my Canon camera body like some forums say.CONS:At least for my copy, these cons were too big to ignore and I sent mine back.Vignetting so bad that it darkened my entire photo when wide open and had horrible vignetting several stops down.Exposure. I had to set the exposure compensation to +5, which on any other lens would blow the picture completely out! Even more, the exposure would differ taking several of the exact same shots one after the other.When zooming from 18-35 I would have to adjust the exposure compensation from either +5 to -6 to keep the same exposure. Yes zooming changed the exposure that much. Same shot, different exposure. Completely unacceptable in my opinion.

Title: Updated review
Reviews: I originally reviewed this lens when it first came out around 5 years ago. It's IQ and quality build is second to none. There is review after review online about how good this lens is. It's interesting that I feel limited on a cropped sensor body when I use a 35mm prime, however, when I have this 18-35 I tend to want more zoom. Canon has the 17-40 f/4 that offers 5mm greater zoom however that lens is no where near as good as this lens. I don't even consider them in the same category. There is one major drawback; not enough to reduce a star, but that is the size and weight of this lens. I took some excellent low light fish photos at the Monterey Bay Aquarium with this lens. I was there for approx 4 hours and it did not weigh too heavy on me. Anything longer than 4 hours might begin to takes it's toll if you are not used to carrying around a heavy lens. Overall I don't think there is another lens like this around. It's in a class of it's own. You can replace a few primes (24 and 35mm) for this lens. I enthusiastically recommend this lens.

Title: Follow some basic rules and you get fantastic results.
Reviews: The reviews are spot on concerning the overallquality of this lens. My first impressions were "WOW". I immediately tried to take indoor pictures to test the lens out and at first I was disappointed. I am a beginner photographer and my pics were not coming out clear. I tested the D5500 on a tripod and my pics were tack sharp. Handheld, they were out of focus to me so I was getting a little anxious. Finally, I decided to research youtube and customer comments about insuring good focus. One tip helped me achieve excellent results. Shutter speed had to be greater than focal length. Yes, once I made sure my shutter speed was high enough, my pictures were in focus and sharp even wide open. I will use a tripod when shooting anything requiring longer than 18 hundreths of a second and pay attention to the shutter speed when shooting handheld. Hope this helps someone out there who is just learning to take great shots.

Title: Terribly Disappointed....
Reviews: Let me preface this review by saying I paired this lens with a brand new Canon 70D. I found it lacking.+ Pros: wonderful build and feel. It feels like an $800+ lens. I only wish it preformed like one. When it did work, it took beautiful shots+ Cons: Focus - The HSM motor was so loud using it for video (which was the point of purchase) was useless. - Liveview focusing would take 3-5 seconds of hunting OR it just wouldn't find focus and the screen would be completely blurry - focus through the view finder was better, BUT it did tend to back-focus and hunt. At times it took 1-2 seconds to lock on to a shot. For $800, I expect the lens to preform better than my canon 24mm that only cost me $130......I don't know if I just received a bad copy or what, but I say stick with Canon. I wanted to give Sigma a chance and it was just sad. I was excited when the pack came and as soon as I took the first shot I knew something wasn't right.Good luck to you and I hope you found this review helpful :D

I honestly do think that this seller got there hands on some sub par, below standard sigma gear and and can afford to offload them on unsuspecting amazon buyers at an attractive price. this is so unfair, what does one in my shoe do in such a situation at this point, i'm not one to complain but felt compelled to warn others as i would want them to do the same for me Be extremely cautious if u decide to shop from this seller.

Name: maskirovka
Title: If you shoot low-light events like dance, performance, or sports you DEFINITELY want this lens
Reviews: This is a review I expect to update as I continue to use my brand new Sigma 18-35mm F1.8 lens. I am not a super-technical pixel-peeper kind of guy but I am a pretty experienced photographer and I'm writing this with a similar audience in mind. I bought this lens because I do a lot of event photography, especially dance (doing volunteer work for a ballet company) and while I've done pretty well with my trusty Canon 24-70mm F2.8 lens, I've felt a bit (sometimes more than a bit) limited when I photograph fast moving dance sequences in the low-light environments stage and dance very often are. That's because the 24-70mm F2.8 simply doesn't do as well on an EOS 7D with its 1.6x (APS-C) crop that it does on a full-frame like my EOS 5D Mark III.That's what's one of the very nice things about this lens. You get the same performance on the crop body with it that you get with the 24-70mm on the full-frame. And that's important because my crop body with its 8 frame per second burst capability is the best camera for catching action (as opposed to the significantly smaller burst capability of the 5D Mark III).07/17/2013:So let's start with the first impressions:1. The price on this lens is great. If it had been Canon or Nikon, I would have expected paying far more than what Sigma is charging for a game-changer lens.2. The build quality is very nice. Holding the lens in my hands, it feels solid and well-constructed.3. Although the lens is not a macro, I was impressed by how close it could focus...I actually was able to get good, sharp images of my parrot's face when I focused in below the ten inches that the specifications say it can do.4. The lens focuses very quickly and the small number of images I've captured with it appear good and sharp. When I open it up, the bokeh appears very nice as well.5. The lens is very quiet...I could hardly hear it while it moved to focus.6. I also think that the lens is fairly low-profile...one wonders if Canon had made it whether they would have made it white which could draw unwelcome attention when doing street photography.As far as negatives go, nothing leaped out at me. Some might not like the fact that you can only stop it down to F16 but who is going to use a lens like this for landscapes?***07/28/2013I'm writing to update this review now that I've been out with my Sigma 18-35mm F1.8 on an EOS 7D body to two events I photographed. My subjects were both the same...the "Nat Pack" entertainers that give t-shirts away and dance on the dugout roof during breaks in the game.I can't figure out how to upload photographs to the review site here (I'd welcome any help on that). In the meantime, you can see the photos from one game that I took on my flickr account photostream. Just go to that website and add after the .com suffix "maskirovka77/sets/72157634795619485/" to see the shots.Frankly, I'm delighted with the lens. Even shooting with it opened all the way up, it was easy to get nice sharp, vivid pictures of the Nat Pack with good bokeh. The lens focused rapidly and I didn't wind up with very many blurry shots at all.I won't even call this a drawback of the lens, since I'm sure that it's a result of optics and mechanical limitations, but the focal length range of the lens is not as good as the 24-70mm F2.8 lens but that's life.One other thing I've realized is that I can pretty much put my old 50mm F1.4 on the market because the Sigma gives me so much more flexibility with its zoom.

Name: Ian
Title: so my love for the Sigma lens might be extremely skewed
Reviews: I needed to upgrade my wide zoom range as I have a big gap between 16mm and 70mm. I was using an old MF Vivitar 28-50mm as my primary lens in this range, so my love for the Sigma lens might be extremely skewed, but the Art lens is gorgeous. The sharpness throughout the f stops is excellent where it is supposed to be, and very good where other lenses would show their weaknesses. Whenever I scroll through my Lightroom catalog without any picture information turned on, it is immediately apparent which pictures were made with the Sigma.One thing I did have to get used to is manually focusing on this lens. I mainly shoot railroad subjects, so I do not have much need to have a quick auto-focus and I learned on an MF/film camera - I'm just most comfortable setting my focus point manually. In the first couple of outings with the lens I caught myself focusing PAST infinity, and thus resulting in very oddly, and out of focus images. I cannot knock the lens for my own learning curve. Just something to be aware of, and I'm not sure I've heard any other comments related to my early problems.Bravo, Sigma. Looking forward to many other future pieces of glass!

Name: DroneDJ
Title: Consistent and accurate focus problem solved????
Reviews: Yesterday:Hi there, I recently bought the 70D and the Sigma 18-35mm....wanted to love the lens but got very frustrated about its inability to consistently get the focus right...I am still in the process of figuring out how to improve it while shooting wide open and am not done testing. However I think it may be related to a very thin focus pane in combination with the way the 70D focusses...see here for more info. [...] I am hesitant to buy the USB hardware for the sigma lens. Also I have already micro-adjusted the lens +20 on both near and far....I hope, I can figure out a way to solve this quickly otherwise I may end up returning the lens....it is just too frustrating to miss focus in so many shots, especially indoors....BTW - I wonder why Sigma has responded to this issue yet....Today:Ok - I think I may have found the solution... for shooting wide open with this lens in combination with the 70D....1) set micro adjustment to +20 far and near2) set camera M, P or C3) shoot in live view mode4) press AF button on top, select Flexizone single5) press magnifier 3x to zoom in 10x (2x = 5x zoom)6) half press shutter to focus7) take photo in focusI ave tried this at 1.8, ISO 200 in dim lit room and got sharp focus in every shot...Works for me. Curious to hear about your experience.Thanks.

Name: Amazon Customer
Title: Killer lens in ever way. I have absolutely zero ...
Reviews: Killer lens in ever way. I have absolutely zero complaints.I know 3rd party lenses often take heat for being cheaply made but this is truly a solid product. I can no longer put filters on it but considering that fall I would absolutely say this product is well made. Oh, and did I mention that sharpness?

Name: bb58
Title: Love this lens
