Name: DIX PIX photo, video, and pro audio
Title: Sharpness of the image using an a6300 in 4K 30fps with metabones speed booster can't be beat for a wide ZOOM lens!!!  STUNNING!!
Reviews: There's NO WAY there's a better video lens for the a6300 (if it is appropriate to use, meaning for being close up, or for wanting to be wide).WELL-- first let me state 2 things, first off, I am using the metabones speed booster adapter for Sony A mount to Sony E mount, and THIS set up sets this lens on FIRE, turning an F1.8 into an F1.3, which is the KING set up PERIOD. There's nothing like it, AND it's affordable.This lens is for APSC sensors, or APSC mode, not for full frame 35mm sensors.ALSO: Use of the metabones focal reducer (speed booster) is best suited for the cropped sensor version you get on the a6300 shooting in 4K at 30fps. When you try to use other modes, even 24fps 4K will cause vignetting on the lower range of focus, and some 18mm to 22mm will have vignetting.NEVERTHELESS--- go ahead and use it in 4K at 30fps, and THIS is just incredible what you get!! less than 2 meters from a subject, you can capture the entire room, and still zoom all the way in, and make your subject larger than life!!I just shot 2 days in the studio in North Carolina, and then an event the following day, all 3 days using this combo, (Sigma 18 35 with metabones speedbooster on a6300).I am certain auto focus is NOT something you would want to mess with, as trying to take stills using auto focus does NOT work, and that is an issue that makes me wish I had purchased the version of this Sigma 18 35 for CANON, and then the more expensive metabones adapter, but THEN be able to use the Sigma MC-11 adapter that is claiming native auto focus! (anyone tried that with VIDEO??)Me and my Dad can't believe what we just saw, even on our old 1080, 63 inch plasma TV, that was the most amazing footage of ANYTHING we have ever seen!! SO sharp, it's like looking through a WINDOW!The mics on the a6300 are WAY better than the a6000 now, and VERY decent, although of course not PRO audio grade.Don't EVEN question it if you are intending to shoot 4K with either the a6300, or using crop mode for your A7sii, and A7rii. For that matter, who has footage from an FS5 or FS7 using this Sigma lens and metabones speed booster?? THEN you could still keep zooming in!! THAT must be just out of control at F1.3!!ALSO-- this must be a monster low-light combo with the A7sii, which I will shoot next chance I get!!GOD!! I just wish I could include footage, but that would be a copyright issue to even send a link at this point, but YEAH, this is PRO grade stuff BY FAR in a VERY in-expensive package for some $2250, a6300/metabones speed-booster/Sigma 18mm to 35mm Art (and a tripod, this lens is not stabilized, and neither is the camera, BUT tripod duty does GREAT, and this has to be the most portable PRO 4K set up you could possibly get, for an amateur level price, for sure!!If you then get a Shogun or similar 4K recorder and monitor, YES, this is in FACT professional grade, although my Atomos Shogun Flame did not arrive in time for my event, forcing me to record internally, which I did with no overheating, and I managed just fine to NAIL focus. My eyes are perfect, but I did use the EVF, not the 3 inch LCD, which is borderline worthless, especially when using a wide lens.SO-- I will be keeping this a6300 in my bag with an A7sii, and A7rii, and of course, this lens is going to be used whenever possible just to get that shockingly SHARP image!!BAD ASS LENS!! Does very well shooting stills too, although using an laea3 could definitely be better auto focus, and using the laea4 would cost you the light you just added with the speed booster adapter.I was happiest using manual focus, and when zooming, it stayed "sharp as a tack", although it is softer on the edges than it is in the center, but it actually is an "ARTSY" effect that looks VERY nice, and puts extra emphasis on the subject in the center, so GREAT for shooting MUSIC events both in a studio environment, and concerts where you are either close, or want to get EVERYTHING in view, (or BOTH-- and then if you stick that on an FS5, you could keep zooming in from there!!) I'll be getting into an FS5 as well, especially now that I have several amazing E mount lenses and adapters.

Name: Joseph T.
Title: Great lens that surpassed my expectations
Reviews: Very smooth auto focus, sharp wide open, and got me to believe in Sigma.After hearing great things about this lens, I made the leap and purchased it. I couldn't be happier, and now a believer in sigma. Now I eagerly anticipate their next ART lens - the 50 1.4. Name: amazon customer
Title: Focus Lottery
Reviews: I read a lot of glowing review of this lens, including on the (Amazon affiliate) dpreview.com and DXOmark.Everybody praised the fantastic performance ... 3 fast primes in one package.Well, this has been my dream since I take photos ... to have truly stunning image quality over a reasonable zoom range so no lens change is needed.So LBA kicked in, and I got this lens.At first, I couldn't believe how soft it is at f1.8. Didn't seem to match the razor sharpness everyone was talking about?!Until ... well ... until I realized that practically no image was in focus!Since my Pentax K3 has a very useful focus fine adjustment, I thought "no problem, lets fix it".A few hours later I gave up:This lens mis-focuses in a way I have never ever experienced before, not even with the most crappy third party lens from 20 years ago!The only way to describe it is "Focus Lottery"!No reproducable front or back focus ... the focus point is all over the place. Essentially random.Is this maybe Sigma's idea of an "art lens"? :)Since all my other lenses focus better than ever on my new K3, I can positively say its not the camera.After some more reading on the web, I realized I am not alone. There seems to be a number of other users with similar problems, since the lens was launched well over a year ago (I bought it in May 2015).Shame on Sigma that this is still not fixed!Thanks to Amazon for a hazzle free return policy!PS:yes, I also read (and can confirm) that it focuses well with life view.Well, this is not an option for me, as I don't use an SLR to be limited to life view.And yes, IF the lens focuses correctly, it exhibits stunning image quality.Actually better than some of my Pentax limited lenses! Shame I cannot use this and have to return to my old trusty Tammy 17-50 2.8 as a walkabout zoom.

Name: Brandi Engel
Title: Love this lens
Reviews: Love this lens! She is my go to and my baby. Creamy bokeh, quite lens too. Only reason for 4 stars is that it is heavy, but that is what you get for great quality glass :)

Name: dfw1417
Title: Excellent Lens - Worth every Penny! Thanks Sigma!
Reviews: This Sigma 18-35mm F1.8 lens is super! I was reluctant to spend this much on a lens. The last zoom lens I purchased was Sigma 28-300mm f3.5-f5.6 for my Canon T2i and it has not been off the camera since I bought it over 3 years ago! Now that I got the Canon T5i I wanted a lens with great low light capability and all of Canon's was over $1000 each!I was impressed from the time I took it out of the box. This feels like a real LENS not a cheap plastic immitation like Canon's kit lens! This is quality from the start! I immediately tested its low light ability shooting in AV priorty mode I chose f1.8 using iso 400 and just a normal 60w room lamp in the bedroom I was able to shoot several shots at about 1/15th sec shutter speed. I tried the low end 1.6 x 18 mm = 28.8 full frame equiv up through 1.6 x 35mm = 56mm full frame equivalent. I was really impressed with the quality and sharpness of the photos from end to end.I am so glad I got this I had it on order for over 30 days with B&H who seemed to take most of the month of September off every time I went to check on my order there was some dumb closing for another Holiday notice, I dont see how they stay in business they are closed more than open!So I cancelled my order and could not find it in stock anywhere! I just happened upon it on Amazon when there was 3 left in stock, with prime shipping trial I got if OVERNIGHT for $4.00 cant beat that!This is the best lens I have owned.Thanks Amazon and Sigma ... your the best!

Name: John
Title: Buy this lens now

Name: Cam Hurd
Title: Love the fat aperture.
Reviews: Amazing lens. The fat aperture is awesome. It's physically solid, and produces a crystal image.

Name: Raymond Young
Title: Lucky enough to get this while it first came out
Reviews: Sigma built this lens like a tank. I was happy how smooth the zoom was. I have other Sigma/Tamron/Tokina lenses where the zoom sounds so mechanical. Every one of course would have wanted this at 18 to 55, but that's what you get for being the first zoom 1.8 out there. The pictures come out brighter in the dark, compared to the actual scene. But I noticed 1/40 1.8 was a minimum shutter speed I needed for my Canon t4i to focus correctly, otherwise at a slower shutter speed it would not focus right in low light at ISO 1600. Shooting at 1/3 stop over, my girlfriend's pictures turned out bright and complementary, smoothing out her complexion.

Name: Hardmf247
Title: Not Sharp
Reviews: Not real happy with the lens. Was just okay out of the box but not better than my kit lens. Actually my kit lens is sharper. Don't know if the lens is defective or if it needs calibrating. Maybe the the lens would be great if I wanted to spend a half-day calibrating it with the Sigma dock but that's not going to happen. The lens should be dead-nuts accurate/sharp out of the box. I simply don't have the luxury of spending that kind of time calibrating something that should have been done by the manufacturer. Maybe I'll return the lens for another...I'll update my review if I get another.Update: I purchased another lens and it is better out of the box than the first. But it still isn't as good as I expected/hoped. I will eventually take the time to calibrate it with the Sigma USB Dock and I'll update again. I should also say that I have a Canon 70D. For now my rating of three stars will remain.

Name: Pat J. Dooley
Title: People say this is like three primes lenses in one
Reviews: People say this is like three primes lenses in one. It is. The f/1.8 is not a gimmick. You can shoot wide open and your images are sharp and free of chromatic distortion. It is a big, heavy lens. But it takes beautiful photographs and lets you blur out backgrounds to perfection. It is also very sharp, much sharper than any kit lens. It has some competition, but it will see a lot of time on my A77ii body.

Name: AJW.1
Title: Hail Sigma!

I seen complaints about the lack of image stabilization but to that I say use a flash and faster shutter speed, put it on a tripod... you can't compete with these images on a crop sensor body!

Name: Barbara D.
Title: I love this lens!
Reviews: Love this lens. Just love it. The extra opening (f 1.8) for low light work are just enough so I can now capture a concert, or people at a dance, without needing a flash or having blur. Clear lens too, and nice bokeh (background blur) when shooting something like a flower. Only drawback is it sometimes takes too long to "hunt" on autofocus -- not always -- otherwise, it's wonderful, and it's a gift to have a lens that stops down to 1.8 that's a zoom, even though it only goes to 35mm. With my APS-C crop-factor the 35 is the equivalent of about 52 mm. I'm so pleased.

Name: edgar
Title: GREAT BUT....

I would say 85% of my shots were out of focus and the rest were SPOT on and very very sharp! I read that you need to tweak the lens by connecting it to your computer via usb but why would i purchase a lens that simply doesn't work rite out of the box plus purchase an adapter to connect to my computer? My 50mm 1.4 and 35mm 1.4 shoot flawlessly and i have been looking for something wider below 20mm for my 80D camera. I would love to keep using this lens but that requires purchasing additional equipment and modifying it in a program that i would have no clue how to use.

Name: Hithem Y. Geddeda

With such low aperture it is perfect for any dark(er) environments compared to kit lens, but the glass on this is incredible, it gives out amazingly sharp images. Props to Sigma on this one.

Name: hector caroro
Title: It's true but it's not that bad. I'm using a 70D body and most of ...
Reviews: Very sharp lens. Other photographers may have issue with the auto focus. It's true! At first it miss 70% of my shot. Please adjust the Lens Micro Adjustment on the body. Be mindful that this lens don't have vibration control so keep the shutter speed @1/200 or above on hand held or as steady as you can. I'm using a 70D body and most of the shot was on point after the lens micro adjustment on the body. I had no auto focus problem after the adjustment. Work like a charm! Yes the lens is very heavy but most lens at this level are. Just like the weight of canon L series. For the quality build and image sharpness, this lens makes up for it. Having 18-35mm wide is very useful. Specially shooting a big group of people.

Name: Vladimir Mischenko
Title: Very nice!
Reviews: Very sharp. Auto-focus is correct and fast enough.A little bit heavy. And zoom range isn't enough sometimes. Not good for the case when you need a quick shot.You also need manually set aperture value if you want nice boke on portrait photos.

Name: Danny
Title: One Star
Reviews: Fouces issue on 80d had to return it.

Name: Mauro D.
Title: Great Lens
Reviews: I did so much research on this lens, and after purchasing it i wasn't disappointed. I sold my canon 24-105L F4 to buy this lens and i don't regret it, it was the best move i could have done since i have purchased my camera.

Name: MidTwentiesDude
Title: Five Stars
Reviews: Absolutely phenomenal lens

Name: Joyful reader
Title: Great lens
Reviews: Love this lens.

Name: J.J.R.
Title: Problems With Sony Cameras???
Reviews: I'm not sure if I got a bad copy or if I'm just having trouble with my LA-EA4 and LA-EA1 adapters compatibility with this lens.First of all, I don't have the Sigma USB mount to check the lens firmware but when I got the lens, the first thing I did was mount it on the LA-EA1 adapter and mount it to my Sony a5100. I had the camera on Manual mode and I can see right away that the camera wasn't reading the F-Stop...just blinking F/.. but I was able to fire off a few shots but then, my LCD screen went blank. Tried turning the camera on and off but seems like my battery died (it was at 45% when start up), I replaced the battery but seems like the a5100 combo with the LA-EA4 and LA-EA1 adapters are not working. Tried it with the LA-EA4 on my Sony A7s and still no F-stop reading and I can see the info of all the settings on my LCD and EVF but can't see through the lens, just a blank screen. After fiddling with it (removing it and re-mounting it, nudging it) the lens kicked in and I could see through the lens but still no aperture reading.I didn't buy this for my E-Mount cameras but for my A77 mark II which hasn't arrived yet. So before I return this lens, I will give it a try with my A-Mount camera once it arrives next week....but still, this lens should work with the Sony E-mount cameras via adapter without all those hiccups.UPDATE: 5/12/2015I'm sure this is a great lens for the cropped sensor cameras but my copy didn't work. Not sure if it's bad QA or a lens software issue but I downgraded to 1 star based on my experience with the SIGMA lens and I wasn't able to take even one shot because in the end, every SONY camera I tried it on didn't even register the lens was there. My last try with the A77 mark II, the camera didn't even power on with this lens on it. I'm returning it and not going to even try for a replacement.

Name: Bob Charlie
Title: Five Stars
Reviews: Amazing!

Name: Sam
Title: Not for a full frame camera.
Reviews: I didn't realize that DC for Sigma means the lens is only compatible on a crop sensor camera. :( ai was really excited to find a sigma art lens at these focal lengths, but alas, I guess I will have to wait for one that works good on a full frame.The vignette on this lens is very strong at 18mm on a full frame camera, and doesn't begin to dissappear until around 24mm.The glass was still good quality and took great few pictures, but since I couldn't use it at 18mm like I desired, I returned it. I would definitely recommend this lens to someone using a crop sensor camera.

Name: J. Greene
Title: Nice quality lens
Reviews: I bought this to use with my  Blackmagic Design Cinema Camera with EF Mount . It is a great match for the camera since it is both wide and fast. It provides a nice normal range for the BMCC's 2.3 crop. On an APS-C DSLR, this would make a great wide lens.There is very little chromatic aberration on this lens compared to a Zeiss Distagon 35mm f2.0 (yes, I'm comparing this lens to a Zeiss). It appears just as sharp as the Zeiss, too. The bokeh is quite smooth. It seems to sharpen up a bit at higher f-stops, but I can see using this lens wide open all the time.The lens seems to be solidly built. It is solid without being too heavy. The focus throw is a good distance and the focus ring is smooth -- just the right amount of resistance and very little play. The lens does not have hard focus stops, but the soft stops are "hard" enough so that it is easy enough to stop when you hit them.

Name: Husaini A.
Title: Five Stars
Reviews: Well the best lens to bring along to any event that has limitation in term of space.

Name: Grant Porter
Title: Five Stars
Reviews: I love this lens. Super sharp images. Easy to focus and extremely versatile.

Name: Steven Thistle
Title: This lens is kickass!
Reviews: Recently bought this Sigma 18-35 F1.8 Art lens (Canon Mount) for my Lumix GH4 and connecting the two with my Metabones Speed Booster. I film a lot of weddings here in Cape Town, South Africa and I needed a lens that was good for "run and gun" shooting. After testing it out quite a bit and shooting a wedding with it, I was pleasantly surprised with just how sharp this lens is! Like.. WOW! I've been a big believer for a long time that zoom lenses just aren't the way to go, because you just don't get the image quality or the sharpness that you do with a prime lens. But this lens might be sharper than some primes that I've been using for a few years now!It is a rather heavy lens though, and coming from a place of using small film camera prime lenses like the Nikkor 50mm F1.8, It took awhile to get used to. But I can't fault the camera on its weight at all because with such a solid casing and that amount of glass elements inside, its so worth the extra weight for the image quality you get!Truly what makes this camera trump any other lens in its class is that beautiful F1.8. I mean for a zoom lens, this lens is FAST! This was a major sell point for me because the GH4's ISO performance is not the greatest at all with that tiny Micro Four Thirds sensor. This lens paired with my Speed Booster has made this lens a lowlight monster, with the ability to shoot more establishing wides at 18mm and beautiful cinematic close-ups at 35mm.I truly can't fault this lens at all after using it for quite a few jobs, and with such a reasonable price tag I can't think of any lens I'd rather want. So if you're looking for a lens that covers the basic focal lengths for a scene, great in lowlight, well built and reasonably priced, then look no further!

Name: Steve G.
Title: Best lens on my Nikon D5200
Reviews: I love with this lens, I never take it off my camera. Super sharp pics and videos. The quality of this lens is flawless feels like silk when adjusting the focus/zoom rings.

Name: stanley sheppard
Title: Problems with Autofocus - Returned Lense

Title: Superb quality - just as expected
Reviews: It really delivers the sharpness you can read about in the reviews. Construction is good, feel is nice, controls convenient. May have slight problems focusing in low light but keep in mind it is not a problem of the lens, it is a problem of camera focusing in such condition where focusing is problematic but shooting is still possible.The nicest bokeh you can find on a crop-factor SLR.

Reviews: Performs as expected.

Title: Four Stars
Reviews: Be careful - it is only for crop sensor cameras.

Name: A. Woodard
Title: Sigma Scores A Home Run!
Reviews: I was lucky enough to purchase this lens during the first batch of shipments. I immediately put it to use for both still and video use with Canon EOS cameras. I honestly could not be more impressed with a lens. It does everything well, including fast accurate focusing, smooth manual focus and zoom. The build quality is outstanding. Even higher than most L series that I own, and very close to the Zeiss ZE line. It has a pleasing bokeh, and minimal vignetting at all focal lengths. During my last four wedding shoots, it is the only lens I have used during the entire reception. Please Note: this lens is designed for APS-C, or cropped sensor camera bodies.It is not compatible with full frame sensor bodies.

Name: Jade
Title: BELOW EXPECTATION
Reviews: This lens was below my expectation. I have used way, way cheaper lenses with better quality in terms of sharpness and just over all quality. Needless to say I was disappointed. I guess that will teach me never to trust the words of those money-hungry YouTubers. They'd straight up lie to you for those sponsored product plus. Its all about the sponsorship to them. This was money wasted. SMH

Name: Kamal Khairi
Title: Best lens for APS-C
Reviews: Sharp, versatile, fastest zoom lens! Kudos to Sigma for making a great general zoom lens and did I mention it's sharp even wide open?

Name: Jim Smith
Title: Great, except focus accuracy
Reviews: Optically impressive. But the focus accuracy is hit or miss. I have to shoot more frames and play with composition to ensure that I get at least one shot that is focused correctly, and then crop it to what the composition should be.

Name: tim velo
Title: Complete waste for professionals
Reviews: Would work great for a crop frame sensor, but on a full frame, most of the focal length shows the outer lens mechanism. Not just a little vignette, but full corners clipped by the frame from 18 - 28 mm. Not sure why I would want to buy a lens that would be worth more than the crop frame camera it would work on. Stick with canon glass if you have anything above a 6D! I'm ashamed that they would even try to sell this as a professional lens.

Name: Jodie Smith
Title: Great lens
Reviews: I love this lens... i have captured amazing shots already...

Name: Darth Rob
Title: Incredible lens, like buying multiple primes rather than one zoom
Reviews: The image quality is exceptional and the lens is sharp even wide open. There's some blue fringing but nothing that can't be easily fixed in RAW processing, but I am just nitpicking now. The build is exceptional - the zoom and focus rings are buttery smooth and nothing like I've experienced yet. It's smoother than some L series I've handled. The HSM is super quiet and completely inaudible in normal noise level environment. One of the things that I was really impressed with was that this lens ships with its own case and hood. Even the case is well made and appears better than the case Canon ships with the L series. Canon stands to learn a lot on that front alone - it's ridiculous that Canon doesn't ship hoods with Non- L series lenses and charges an additional $50-100 depending on the lens for the hood.The minimum working length is around 12 cm making it fairly useful even for macro photography. The 9 bladed aperture gives excellent round bokeh. All in all, this could be an excellent walk around lens suited for equally well for Landscapes, Reporting, or Portraits. As far as a crop sensor goes, it really doesn't get better than this as far as lens to price ratio goes. FYI, DxO Mark ranked this as the best crop sensor lens they have reviewed yet.I've had this lens for less than a week now and these are my initial impressions. I will update this review after I've used it for a bit longer.

Name: TheFyend
Title: 4 hours of my life wasted, did nothing
Reviews: Junk. Can't autofocus to save it's life. Tried on T5i, T6i, 80D.. used USB dock to calibrate... 4 hours of my life wasted, did nothing.

Name: Amazon Customer
Title: The zoom capabilities are limited which I knew when I bought it (it's still better than nothing)
Reviews: I have a Canon EOS 70d, and I bought this lens after reading reviews praising its versatility and quality. I was excited about its wide aperture and zoom capabilities. However, this lens can not focus!! All my photos turn out blurry, and as I have done more research, many people seem to have the same problem. The zoom capabilities are limited which I knew when I bought it (it's still better than nothing). The autofocus will not work with the camera, and the quality of my videos are terrible with this lens. The much cheaper lens that came with the camera is far better in quality than the Sigma. I am very disappointed in this product and would advise caution in your decision to purchase it. I know people have said buying a Sigma mount has improved the focus capabilities, but I am not willing to pay more money for a lens that should work in the first place.

Name: KMan
Title: Wow!
Reviews: When dxomark said "[w]ith the introduction of this model, Sigma has the best performing zoom of its type," they weren't kidding.I've only taken a few pictures but you can get that dreamy blur look at 2.8. The sharpness is to die for and color is spot on.I'll update with photos later on.

Title: great stuff!
Reviews: just as advertised. fast shipping and a great lens. definitely recommend these folks!! seven six five four three two one.

Name: Kendall Jones
Title: So Far So Good
Reviews: I haven't used it much yet but impressed with it so far. Beautiful and sharp images but it is quite a bit larger than I expected.

Name: jedcal
Title: One Star
Reviews: More than half of the photos taken on the 70d were out of focus

Name: curious
Title: Not as good as other reviews mentioned. Perhaps, I got a bad copy...
Reviews: I was very excited when I was informed that the lens was available and I would get it in a few days. This excitement quickly turned into disappointment after taking a few shots with this lens.The first shot is very blurry. It is so bad up to the point that it is like out of focus. I said to myself: Ok, this was probably because the lens doesn’t have IS, and the shutter was just 50. So I increased the shutter speed to like 60, which is about 1.6 times the focal length of 35. The result is almost the same: the picture is very, very soft. I continued increase the shutter speed in the hope of getting a shot with a decent sharpness. Unfortunately, this didn’t come. Again, I said to myself: let me try it outdoor. Pictures that are taken outdoor are better, but I don’t get the kind of sharpness many other reviewers mentioned. The sharpness is just “ok”, nothing spectacular. I got better sharpness with my kit lens Canon 28-135, and much better sharpness with the Canon 17-55.Another deal breaker of this lens for me is the indoor focus speed. It lags quite a bit in focusing when trying to take photo indoor in the evening.On the plus side, the build quality is no doubt the top notch. The zoom and focus rings are so smooth, and the internal focus is definitely good in term of no dust will get into the lens through external barrel movement.Because of many great reviews of this lens out there, I wonder if it is because I got a bad copy.

Name: S. Peter Lewis
Title: Yes, it surely is a "bag of primes"
Reviews: I've been a pro shooter for over 30 years and use primes almost exclusively. This lens equals or beats my primes in the same focal-length range. And with a 1.8 max aperture, it truly gives full frame bokeh on APS-C cameras. It's built like a tank, has very smooth zoom and focusing rings, and there is essentially no chromatic aberation, even wide open. Yes, the auto-focus can be spotty, but don't let that deter you: it's quite easy to fix with your camera's micro adjustments, and in live view and manual it's perfect anyway. This is just about the finest APS-C lens I have ever used. Sigma hit this one completely out of the park!

Name: Pete
Title: Fun lens but with limitations
Reviews: As with all of Sigma's recent lenses, this one is very sharp throughout it's zoom range. Also like Sigma's recent lenses, the autofocus does hunt a little before acquiring the subject. It's not much of an issue, this is obviously not a sport lens, more of a street photography lens or wider angle portrait lens.I was hoping to also use this lens for video.... but I adapt my lens to a Sony body.... Adapting lenses for video is NEVER a good idea and I would not recommend it. The autofocus motor is constantly active with micro-adjustments and it makes a ridiculous amount of noise. I even tried with an external mic but it's still too much.

Name: Mp Vision
Title: I love love this lens!!!
Reviews: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.  Oh how I love this lens! I rented it for an event where I was incredibly worried about the low light. Well this lens on My canon 70D and it was all heaven! I was so happy with it that I just had to get it. I did, 2 weeks later. This is now My go to walk around lens. I don't have any technicals for you, but I am here to tell you that this lens is absolutely amazing for video. This is My first Sigma Art lens and I am sure this will not be My last. Check out the video I rave about it there.

Name: Hawki Pierce
Title: Exceptional Lens ... Another winner from Sigma
Reviews: I had the opportunity to rent this lens to shoot a wedding with my, then new, Pentax K-3. I wanted something that I could use with natural light in both a Church and reception hall setting. After all I had read about this lens, it wasn't hard to choose it for this job.First of all, this lens is ground breaking in it's scope and design. There is nothing else like it when it comes to zoom convenience coupled with the ability to shoot below f2.0 and as sharp as any prime lens within it's range.This lens is quite sharp right from f/1.8 and is brutally sharp from f/2.8 on. I had zero problems with the focusing system and had only 4 shots from the entire wedding that were out of focus by any noticeable degree. Contrast and Color saturation were first rate and when it came to Post Processing, I had very little to do.The lens is a little heavy, but what exceptional glass isn't?The build quality is as good as it gets, with the materials used and the fit and finish being state of the art in all ways.Between my K-3's very quite shutter and the Sigma's HSM focusing system, I was never intrusive during the ceremony.I can't really speak to any of the other systems that this lens is available for, but when it comes to Pentax ... there is nothing else remotely like it available. I can easily recommend this lens to any Pentax user that is looking for a low light, wide angle lens capable of zoom convenience with the speed and sharpness of a prime.Pricing for this lens makes it one of the best values on the market for pro quality and performance.

Name: Brian
Title: Sset to a single focus point and aim that at an area of high contrast (like an eye)  or may seem out of focus
Reviews: I have it mounted on a Canon 7D2 and the image quality I am getting is incredible. When shooting wide open at F1.8 I find I must set to a single focus point and aim that at an area of high contrast (like an eye) if you let the camera pick its own area there is a good chance that things will appear out of focus. Not a problem with the lens just a product of shooting at f1.8. I recently took this into the Cathedral in DC and even in the basement crypt with very low light I was able to shoot wide open at f1.8 handheld and got some very good shots. (I found out that the cathedral does actually allow tripods, but the review is of the lens, not my ability to plan ahead). I have a sample photo below that shows the detail that is picked up. Likewise I added a photo from the Airforce Memorial in DC with a crop to show detail (it is a pano of two photos) and a close up of a stone carved head in a case to show how it throws elements out of focus.All these photos are because I don't think I can explain the detail this gets, there is a little bit of CA and Vignetting, but for the most part that is a one button fix. The light transmission is incredible, this is not just an F1.8 lens but it is also a T Stop 1.8. I was a bit nervous pulling the trigger on this lens, as I see a good few one star reviews talking about focus problems, I cannot speak to what those folks are seeing, it is possible that there are some dud lenses out there, but my personal suspicion is that a lot of the problems are due to depth of field

Name: IBRAHIM Y
Title: Was fine in First 2 months, But now in Dec 2014 " the Subject too dark " not work well
Reviews: I bought Nikon 35mm f/1.8G AF-S DX Lens before Sigma 18-35mm 1.8 , its Amazing and then I bought Sigma on 8th of March 2014 from Amazon The Seller in Amazon The Camera Shop of Lansing.When tried Sigma after Nikon Lens 35mm f/1.8 its completely like Nikon 35mm 1.8 in Low lights, but now after few months the results so bad the Simga lens after re-installed and take the first picture, the lighting too DarkMaybe these defect manufacturersI have not used it for a long time, maybe first two months, and then left it in the bag, then tried it before one day in 17th December 2014Now When I compare Sigma 18-35mm 1.8 for Nikon with the Nikon Lens 35mm 1.8 does not gives the same results as in the past. Name: primeguy
Title: All APS-C user must have..... all around.
Reviews: I give 5 star because of the performance and the price range. it might be too early to give it a rating but I'm confidents I have a good copy.I will update my reviews later if needed.I have my eyes on this Art Lenses long before I decided to get the 18-35mm for my canon 7d. I got mine in the store at the big photo show and I have plenty of time to test it first out of the box before buying the lens. I bought the first lens I was testing. I did not bother to remove it from my camera and the store have no problem with it.Ok, here's my first observation of handling the lens on my camera. Beautiful Plastic Body and Nice to carry (weight is heavy for some but not for me), just imagine carrying 5 lens (18-20-24-28-3)5 in one. The motor is very quite and I'm very impressed (test video also). the Lens hood and the Cap are OK.Both adjustment ring are a little tight but very smooth.This will be my Walk around lens from now on and will be my back up for my 5D mk2,Done my focusing test at the store and the sales rep at the store was really helpful, they leave me alone. It probably take me 15 - 35 mins before I decided my purchase. I got my copy on the first box I tried. I did not purchase the USB Dock cause I think do not need it and it will not work on my Sig 85mm F1.4 also.... I'm lucky on this one too and this is on my 5d mk2 all the time.So, if you want this lens I suggest going to your local store and tried it first and learn how to perform focus test.One more I notice on this lens right away that really blow me away... is the manual focus (lens) is super sharp at F1.8. WOW! The auto focus work great also but maybe just me...the MF is much sharper. The draw back is that it was only design for the Crop Sensor. On Canon this lens will be (18)28.8mm to (35)56mm.This is a keeper lens.

Name: GT
Title: Game Changer Lens with my Canon 70D!!!
Reviews: I bought this lens Nov 2014. I am a very active event/party photographer and have taken 40,000+ shots with this lens. It is my pride and joy and just about never comes off of my Canon 70! Before purchasing this, my main lens was Sigma's 17-50 f/2.8, which I really LOVED because it took awesome pictures, had great autofocus even in low light, and the 17-50 range made it very versatile for nice short range shots! However, turns out I didn't know what love was until I bought my Sigma 18-35! I was a little hesitant to buy it at first since I already had a lens that covered short range shots, but the thought of possibly having the equivalent of 3 1.8 prime lenses in one made it very tempting. I was/am always looking for ways to improve my work, so I took the dive and it was one of the best investments I've ever made! Now, my old love (the Sigma 17-50 2.8) is used as a backup and never sees any action.However, it wasn't love at first use though. When I first received my lens in Nov 2014, it was spontaneously having focusing issues. Prior to purchasing this lens, I did read a few reviews from other people stating their Sigma 18-35 was having focusing issues with their Canon 70D and that it was hit or miss if you had gotten a good or bad copy. At times, I did feel like mine was one of the bad copies as my camera was very slow to focus (about 3 or 4 seconds) even in a well lit environment. I didn't want to go through the hassle of sending it back to Sigma for inspection and repair, so instead I bought the $60 Sigma USB dock to see if updating the firmware would fix the issue. Fortunately, after doing so my lens is now tack sharp and auto focus is extremely quick! Not only is it quick, but it is able to focus in extremely low light conditions, which is very important for me when taking pictures of people dancing when the lights are dimmed. You can also make micro adjustments with the front and back focusing using the USB dock, but beware- it isn't user friendly at all. You might as well work for Sigma if you are able to figure it out! Fortunately, I didn't have to make any micro adjustments and a simple firmware update was able to resolve my focusing issue with my 70D.I also really love the build quality of this lens. The feel and the grip of it just feels like you are holding something of really, really high quality. It is on the heavy side (compared to my 17-50 and other lenses), but it is something you will get used to. In terms of weight, you can't make everyone happy anyway. Too light, people will complain it feels cheap. Too heavy, people will say, well... it's too heavy. I say man up because the pictures that come out of it are truly amazing. On the bright side, my right bicep and forearm are now a tab bit bigger thanks to the weight of this lens lol.I do miss the extra range that my 17-50 offered, but I've adapted to it by just moving with my feet, which means I've also increased my cardio :)Thanks so this lens, I have no reason to upgrade to a $3,500 full frame camera. This lens is truly a hidden gem for crop sensor cameras. Definitely 5 stars all the way! Great work Sigma! Now, if you can please make a Sigma 18-200 f/1.8 EX DG OS HSM Macro Art lens, that would be awesome- and please price it under $1,000 :)

Name: S. Arora
Title: Crazy sharp, but...
Reviews: The reviews are absolutely right; this is an extremely sharp lens; better than primes in this focal range. I used it for a year and a half.But, over time I began to feel this len lacks "character." The photos never pop off the page. On one trip to Africa I had this lens, and a "fun" camera: the tiny Coolpix A. now discontinued. I'd pull it out for a quick snapshot, and I consistently found myself liking its rendition over the Sigma.(Don't be surprised; on the internet you'll find serious reviewers saying the coolpix A's lens is better than most Leica lenses of that focal length. THough it is not quite as sharp as the Sigma.)Ultimately, I decided that I'd much prefer the coolpix A over the big Sigma lens + D7100 combo, plus it weighs 1/5th as much! So the Sigma is now sold. Sharpness isn't everything. An interesting lesson.

Name: Amazon Customer
Title: So sharp; so frustrating!
Reviews: TL;DR - you will need the calibration dock and to spend many hours fiddling with it.Do you like things that don't work out of the box, but can be made to (mostly work) after hours of customization/calibration? Then this is for you.I've tried this on a 7D and a 7D mark ii. On both cameras most images are completely out of focus prior to calibration. After calibration many pictures are in focus, but it is far from perfect.The lens is quite slow to achieve focus. For example, taking pictures of small children is almost pointless. Kids tend to move faster than the lens can focus, whereas my L lens keeps up.When the lens does focus the sharpness is really impressive. Color and absence of fringing are also impressive.Calibration took me ~3 hours in the first session, and another hour a day later to refine. ...and then two more hours a couple weeks later to address a couple ranges that were consistently front focused.If you are willing to buy the lens calibrating dock, spend a fair bit of time calibrating, and mostly take pictures of slow or stationary things, then this lens is fine.If I could do it over I'd spend more and get a Canon L.

Name: two dachshunds
Title: What can I say?
Reviews: Not sharp enough to out- resolve a 24 megapixel sensor but close enough..... Closer than any Nikon lens will take you.I have Sigma 18-35 on backorder with Adorama that I will have to cancel and I will never do business with those morons ever again. Adorama is going to send me a check for $560 for 4 Nikon lenses (16-85mm, 50 1.4D, 85 1.8G and a kit lens 18-55) – after promising me $800 only hours earlier.

Name: Loreley
Title: Out of focus most of the time
Reviews: Let's start with the positives. This lens has amazing sharpness and its focal length and constant aperture are huge pluses for me. The build quality is excellent.The downfall of this lens is that the autofocus is completely garbage. I shoot with a Canon 7D and without tweaking anything via the Sigma USB dock, I'd probably get about 80% of images out of focus. With hours of tweaking using the USB dock, it performs better but it's far from reasonable (1 fail in every 3 or 4 shots).I would not recommend getting this lens unless you plan to use manual focus or live view focusing (slow!). The only thing holding me back from giving this 1 star is that I'm still hoping a magical firmware appears one day a that will fix all the AF issues (2018.06.12 still doesn't fix it).

Name: Jonathan
Title: If it could only focus properly....
Reviews: This lens has trouble focusing on the Canon 70D. 85% of my shots were out of focus so I had to return it. Also, this lens is simply too heavy. The build quality is outstanding. The colors and bokeh are beautiful. It's a very promising lens but it needs a diet and more accurate focusing. Even at small apertures and very fast shutter speeds it was almost impossible to capture a sharp image.

Name: Conrad
Title: Not as good as all the hype.  But still impressive.  No in lens stabilization.
Reviews: I bought this lens with a MetaBones Speedbooster for my micro four thirds camera.It is bright and sharp. No in lens stabilization. It is also the noisiest auto-focus on the planet, and slow focusing, IMHO. Why? I am really, why does it have to SO NOISY! For video with manual focus, I found it difficult to keep the image sharp with large aperture. If you are film maker and can retake over and over until you master pulling focus for your scene, then great. But for spontaneous video, which I shoot. I found it difficult. I have some fast primes that focus like lightning, and the results are superior, no question about it. I lose too much video to the trash can with this lens. So I'll probably sell it. I will test it a bit more first, because there is a certain appeal to it related to it's speed.A few facts. Used with my .64 Metabones Speed Booster, the focal length is 26.5-51.5mm, and by gaining 1 1/3 stops it becomes an f/1.1 lens. A marvel! I have a native lens 12mm f/1.4, 25mm f/1.4 and a 42.5mm f/1.2, all this extremely fast auto-focus, so do I need the zoom? Do I need the extra bit of brightness? In dark situations, or for bokeh, maybe. Maybe not. I have plenty of zooms that cover wider ranges in brighter conditions. Unless I want that bokeh, which I can get with my primes. And that is exactly what makes it so hard to focus. Which means I need to stop down a few stops to open up the depth field. So you see what I mean, the big advantage of this lens is nullified. By the way, the zoom motion was not all that smooth and is something you would need to practice. So if you want this to be your only lens, practice constantly. Even so I think you may be dissatisfied with the focal lengths and want something wider at times. I didn't find the range of the zoom all that useful. 26.5-51.5mm? It may be different for your application as this lens was designed for a variety of crop format camera. In any event, for me, it is way too narrow a band for a zoom, and of limited usefulness. I think my fix focal length primes would work better, and zooming is overrated for video. Fixed focal length, steady shots, several angles and lenses would work better. Perhaps at fixed focal lengths and perfect focus. I'm thinking my f/2.8 zoom might be fine if I every need zoom for video (doubtful) or even one of my power zooms, coupled with my fast primes are sufficient.Why haven't I sold it yet? It has to do with the Speed-booster I use it with to mate up to my Micro Four Thirds Panasonic cameras. I have a GH4, and a GX85 with IBIS. Each camera has it's advantage--the GH4 for video, and the GX85 for image stabilization.Speed-booster: You are supposed to gain 1 1/3 stops of light using a Speed-booster with this lens. It's the reverse of a tele-converter. A 1.4x tele-converter loses one stop, a 2x tele-converter loses 2 stops--if you know the math behind apertures. The Speed booster give you back that light by concentrating it on a smaller sensor. You gain light. It's a miracle. So that makes this aperture f/1.1 which is exactly what my GH4 shows. Astoundingly fast. And it is true. I was shooting a f/1.1 with this f/1.8 lens. I compared it at the top end 51.5mm on a GH4 against a 50mm prime, both at f/1.4 and the exposures were 1/5 of a sec compared to 1/6 of a second, essentially dead nuts right on. Some people say you have to apply a crop factor to the aperture. I don't find that to be the case in the real world. So you can see, I'm going to test this lens out more thoroughly before I consider selling it. I love low light photography. It gains 2/3 of a stop over my 25mm lens, and 6/10 of a stop on my fastest, sharpest prime Not all that much of a difference. And those two lenses take up less space than this lens. Most likely I will be closing down this lens slightly in any event, which nullifies the speed advantage. I will definitely keep the speed booster, and think about the lens. I bought it for the Canon mount, because I anticipate buying Canon glass in the future.Final thoughts: I like the Canon mount. I'd like to start to acquire some Canon glass so that when the make the camera I want, in a few years, I'll have the glass before I buy the body.NOTE: Pictures show both camera bodies and the mating Speed Booster Interface.

Name: Chris Basden
Title: Awesome Lens!
Reviews: I'm primarily a video shooter. The value in this lens is simply unparalleled! It's been said in every product review out there, but there's just not another option if you need a fast, wide zoom lens for crop-body cameras. I'm using with an 80D, but I'll have this lens long after that camera's dead and gone. I plan to upgrade to an EOS R (Full frame, but you can use this lens with that body in crop mode) eventually, but as "outdated" as my 80D is, I'm getting great results using this lens. This is a no-brainer buy!

Name: Brittany U
Title: How do I love thee? Let me count the ways.
Reviews: I just cannot say enough positive things about this lens. This was probably the most expensive lens I've ever bought, I try to buy used and otherwise hunt for deals on lenses that are ~300 or less, so needless to say I was a little hesitant to drop $800, but man was it worth it. This lens performs as if it were three times the price at least. I've always been a fan of wide-angle images, and on my 35mm camera I loved the way my 28mm 2.8 created the perfect mixture of depth but gave that "context" of a wide angle, something you lose with telephoto lenses. This lens is sharp, collects amazing light, has beautiful color, has a great build quality... I can't say enough things. My favorite lens.

Name: thatmanphil
Title: Love it! (it's kinda big)
Reviews: The first thing you'll notice about this lens is that it's big and heavy. People say it's like owning three fast primes in one; i say it's also like carrying three fast primes in once. Attached to my 80d I find myself holding the kit buy the lens instead of the body. But it's well worth the fast aperture and image quality. Even shot wide open at f1.8 pictures are very sharp and predictable. Don't let the limited zoom range put you off, 18-35 is extremely useful and is perfect for street photography, travel, events, and portraits. With this lens you really can get a pro level look to your images. The full time manual focus is the icing on the cake here, and i find myself preferring to focus manually at times.The only con is it's size. The lens hood just has to come off if it's going in the camera bag.p.s. I did have to adjust the autofocus micro adjustments in my camera to get accurate focusing as it had some serious front focusing issues.

Name: Mason G. Williams
Title: Inspired a love for photography
Reviews: My wife and I had purchased a Canon Rebel T3i about 3 years ago and after the initial excitement of owning a DSLR camera wore off, the camera spent the majority of that time in the closet next to it's box. The images just didn't pop like we expected them to. After learning a little bit about photography (aperture priority mode is your friend!) we decided to bite the bullet and get a good lens and let me tell you the difference between this lens and the kit lens is night and day. The colors are vivid and the images pop straight out of the camera.We took the lens to Europe with us in September and then to Vietnam this spring and we absolutely treasure the shots we got with it. The bokeh it produces is amazing and the fact that you can hold the 1.8f throughout the entire focus range really makes a big difference! None of these photos received any editing.I cannot recommend this lens highly enough as it turned us from iPhone photographers to artists. You will not regret purchasing this lens.

Name: Tyson Hunsaker
Title: The workhorse of workhorses
Reviews: Sigma Art 18-35mm is legendary for a reason. This lens is shockingly sharp and fast throughout the aperture and zoom range. It's beautifully renders the image and the craftsmanship and build quality is stellar. Sigma takes care of their art lenses and its obvious their more affordable lenses in the Art series lives up to the name of Sigma. This lens doesn't however have image stabilization so be aware of this. It's also very sharp and "clinical" as some have called it which means it doesn't have much "character" so be aware. I personally love that in a lens so it's perfect for me.

Name: Lens Therapy
Title: Masterpiece by Sigma
Reviews: A little about me, I do photography part-time and I normally shoot on my D7100. I like to play with different brands and have used Tokina, Rokinon, and Tamron, along with my Nikon and Sigma lenses. The amazing quality of this lens has stopped me from moving up to full frame.I have multiple primes but due to the performance of this lens I have stopped using them, It's such a pleasure to use. It's on the heavier side but once you get used to the heft you wont want to take it off your camera body. The quality of the photos are amazing, you can get creamy bokeh comparable to some full frame cameras. I used it recently at a family party and a quick headshot of a friend turned out so great it's going on his Christmas card. You wont be disappointed by this masterpiece by Sigma.

Name: Competitive runner from DC
Title: Well built well constructed lens, but has focus problems with Nikon DX bodies
Reviews: This lens is fantastic except for one major problem: it is not calibrated correctly for Nikon bodies. This lens consistently misses focus, regardless of aperture. On manual focus, you will see how sharp it is. But on auto focus - center spot - it misses focus at least half the time.

Name: Baffmasta
Title: BEASTLY LENS
Reviews: This lens is amazing. I have it paired with the sony a6500, but have used it also with the sony a7III and also the sony SF5.I would recommend this to anyone looking for a sharp lens with both wide and close range of shooting.I have had mine for 4 months now and would not trade it for the world.

Name: Erick Breneman
Title: I love this lens
Reviews: Got this from another vendor, as my wife wanted to get for Father's day and it was backordered here. Heavy, but needs to be to get that f/1.8 across the range of zoom. I love this lens. It acts like a prime lens for quality, crisp clean images. Having the ability to take a picture of an entire house from the sidewalk on the same side of a street, or an entire side of a car that is only 10 or so feet away is awesome. The little bit of zoom to 35mm (56mm equivalent on my canon t4i) is a great normal eye-width view. I've only had for a few weeks, but it rarely leaves my camera.I have a 40mm pancake prime f/2.8 that is super small and great, but it ends up being a little too narrow of a view for a any indoor use, great for when outside and walking around. This lens is almost that long, but goes so much wider. The other lens I have is the 18-135mm kit lens, which is 3.5-5.6 and is only really useful outside, or inside on a bright sunny day, without going up to 1,600 or higher ISO.If you have some extra cash and your looking for a good indoor (or anywhere) lens, don't be afraid to stretch your budget if you are thinking of spending less. You will get a lot of use out of this lens.

Name: alexw
Title: Genuinely stupendous
Reviews: I cannot recommend this lens enough. I would probably buy it at $1000, it's that good. And the only reason for the discount over other L glass is that 18-35 is a somewhat limiting range. Everything you get within this lens' capabilities though is absolutely without compromise. Wide open at 18mm?Flawless results. Wide open at 35mm? It's like you're shooting full frame with a pro quality 24-70 2.8. Stopped down anywhere in the range? Great stars. Shooting straight into the sun? Classy, not overwhelming flares. It's absolutely wonderful at everything it does, and if you find compromises, you're looking much too hard in the corners off-axis wide open against a brick wall.If you can handle nailing focus at f/1.8 (and it does take skill), you will get nothing but fantastic results from this lens.

Name: Kamk
Title: Great lens, but very heavy.
Reviews: I've only had the lens for 1 day, but I think so far the quality is wonderful. I was able to get a shot of all the food on our table from my seated position, and take some nice, crisp closer shots. I wish I could take off half a star because this lens is extremely heavy. I use this with my Sony A6400 + Sony A to E mount adapter + the lens and it weighs almost 7lbs.

Name: Christopher
Title: Lens is physically longer than I wanted
Reviews: I should have read the physical dimensions before purchasing. The lens is too long for my situation. The photos I took with it are high quality, but it's just a little too bulky for me to actually use on a regular basis.

Name: Majstor
Title: BUYER BEWARE: Returned product - known auto focus problems
Reviews: I returned the product, because the auto focus is non-existent and always miss-focuses. Front AND sometimes back focuses randomly (tested it extensively with view-finder and live-view). Just look it up online and you will find other people having the same issue. I used mine with a Canon 80D. Only buy if you're using exclusively manual focus for video and/or photo.

Name: Dennis
Title: Superb!
Reviews: Superb Lens! I use this with my D7200 and it's an excellent pair for taking photos of events, landscapes, etc. It's not much of a portrait lens due to it's short focal length; ie does not flatter appearances as subjects appear slightly wider than they actually are. However, for my needs, it's perfect! I bought this off Adorama and for the same price on Amazon; I received a sigma docking station for free. Fortunately for me, my lens did not need to be configured as the front and back focusing were good. The free sigma docking station is very useful however for future sigma lenses, and I do intend on purchasing more from this brand considering how well they've made the Sigma 18 35 1.8.

Name: Abi
Title: its a very good lens with fantastic IQ and sharp
Reviews: its a very good lens with fantastic IQ and sharp.,just the limited range and a little bit of sound while auto focus in video and hence have to use an external mic.,it can replace 4 primes in your bag.,28,35,50 and maybe a macro .,nothing like this out there.

Name: Mister M
Title: Terrible AF performance
Reviews: I just got this combo and i did adjust the lens in-camera already. Everything was working perfectly fine and getting sharp images. Last week I shot at my kid's school play in the auditorium. The lights were turned off for the entire show and only with the spot lights toward the stage. No problem, ALL my photos came out perfectly focused and sharp.Today, we had another show at the same place but this time with those ugly auditorium lights turned on and with no spot lights and after seeing my photos in lightroom LOTS of the photos are front focused. What the heck?! I mean, I clearly had the focus point on the person on the stage standing still, but the person in front approximately three stinking yards away was in focused. how did that happen? Well, from what I have been told this lens behaves this way in different types of artificial light.Again, this clearly does not look like a calibrating issue and I know I don't need the hub, and I'm certain is not the D500 doing that. This to me is not good at all. I honestly cannot comprehend how sigma is selling garbage like this, to me this is completely unacceptable. I'm giving sigma two thumbs down. I'm really really disappointed because i thought this lens was THE perfect choice for the amazing D500. What a major let down.Thank god I didn't do any paid jobs with this lens, that would have been a nightmare and I'm glad I caught this issue on time to return it.

Name: Veritas
Title: It would have been a perfect DX lens...but...
Reviews: I bought this lens to use in my Nikon d5300 which was my backup camera for a trip to Thailand. It worked BEAUTIFULLY. Awesome wide angles, with crisp images and great color saturation.Now why 4 stars instead of 5: you'll NEED to work very hard to make this lens work as intended.First, you need to start with a camera that came with a well tuned Auto Focus off the bat. As it turns out my d5300 did. Nonetheless, I spent a good 1+hr calibrating the lens using the Sigma USB adapter (so add $60 to the cost of the lens).But, if your camera has AF problems out from the factory, you are out of luck again. I recently bought a refurbished d7100 and I was getting awful out of focus images with this lens, even with the best light.After much internet research and testing, I figured that AF issues are a common cause of returned cameras that end up being sold as refurbished. Hence, I ended up spending another non-trivial amount of time fine tuning the AF system for this and all my lenses. Now I feel is half decent. Will need to run more tests to compare the performance between the d5300 and d7100 after the AF adjustment. I certainly would not want to re-run the lens calibration because at least I know it works fine with the d5300.Bottom line, many of the negative reviews here are likely from folks that did not know that they needed to spend a tremendous amount of time calibrating this lens and your camera, or both, to work properly. If you are one of those, make sure you buy brand new, non-refurbished, cameras or buy same brand name lenses (at a higher price tag of course).UPDATE Nov 2015: I got a different d7100 body and went through the whole recalibration process again. Love the results, BUT I just can't manage to get autofocus to work at 18mm wide open. With any other length it is sharp as a tack, it is just at 18mm that it get blurry results focusing to infinity. Did I get a bad copy?

Name: Amazon Customer
Title: Amazing sharpness and lens, but adjustments needed.
Reviews: I bought this lens from a vendor not on amazon but I’m very happy with this lens! It is incredibly sharp and probably one of the sharpest lenses for and APS-C camera at the moment. With it being at 18-35mm, it doesn’t have much range but it is great from landscape photography, and I use it as an unconventional portrait lens at 35mm. If you are worried about bokeh, it is just buttery smooth. You may have to buy the sigma dock to do some focus adjustments as I found my copy to front focus a lot at first. Once you get the adjustments in, it is just amazing. Shooting into direct sun it doesn’t have too much chromatic abberation and only some glaring but it’s not too bad. This lens does really well in low light as well. It is definitely a more expensive lens for APS-C cameras but I say after lens adjustments it is a highly capable lens. I didn’t give 5 stars because of the slight focusing issue but other than that I would say it’s worth the buy!

Name: Chris from Edmond, OK
Title: BEWARE - Autofocus Issues renders this lens worthless.
Reviews: Used with a Canon 7d Mark II. 4 out of 5 shots fail to focus correctly. Close enough to look sharp and fool you in the viewfinder...but disappointment is waiting for you once you view full size. All those amazing shots you thought you got were actually ruined.The large aperture on this lens is great, right? That does mean a shallow depth of field, however. Trust me...you'll see just how shallow it is when the lens front focuses every single one of your shots by a couple of inches.I exhausted my return window believing I was doing something wrong. Maybe I was shaking the camera, or using the wrong AF point? I finally got fed up and set up a test rig with tripod and a focus test chart. Unfortunately, it is the lens...Google "Sigma 18-35 front focus" See if this is something you want to risk dealing with.Don't lose your money on this! If you bought this lens and think you must be doing wrong (considering all the glowing reviews), don't be fooled! Return it now...don't wait a couple of months before you realize it really is the lens causing these problems.

Name: B. W. Sharp
Title: My "Go-to" lens for almost every situation!!
Reviews: I have now had this lens for about 6 months and it just keeps getting used more and more. I used it to shoot a concert last night in really poor lighting and not a single good angle. This was the only lens for this environment, it delivered sharp pictures in very low light. I use a 7D and the lens is not treated well by me as I walk around it still looks like the day I bought it. This is my first Sigma lens but it won't be my last based on this model. Only con I can think of is that it is very heavy and it does not focus lightning fast when moving but is very quick on fixed objects. Highly recommend to anyone shooting with a APS-C sensor.

Name: Amazon Customer
Title: Awsome Lens......Absolutely no regret buying it over Canon 16-35 F4
Reviews: Used it for trip to Torres Del Payne, Chile and OMG I stuck with it with Canon 60D....fantastic lens. Why can't Sigma make it as FF?? Please Sigma make FF version and I am willing pay more than what you were charge right now, seriously.I returned Canon 16-35 F4 and chosen to keep this one instead even it is made for APS-C. Sharpness, almost no CA at F1.8, and building quality are the main reasons that I decided to keep this one over Canon 16-35 F4.

Name: bryan
Title: Game on
Reviews: Probably the best lens I have yet to use for a crop body camera. Solid and very well constructed, impressive. The focus ring and zoom ring both rotate firm and smooth, no clunking around. Auto focus is fast and accurate, no in-camera adjustments needed. I use this on the Canon 7D (MK I) and strongly believe I just "upped" my game as far as professionalism and quality is concerned.Thank you Sigma for making such an excellent lens.... PLEASE do something like this for the 2.8 class 70-200 or higher.-Chicago

Name: NY's
Title: Go ahead and buy it.....it's an amazing lens.
Reviews: I have been using this lens for the last 3 weeks and so far it has exceeded my expectations. Even nikon lenses don't have the image sharpness that this provides. Performs better than my nikkor 50mm. Don't debate...buy it. It is a keeper.Cons: slightly heavier than other lenses, Not telephoto and no VR...but in my experience I didn't miss the VR feature at all. The lens is producing just awesome and sharp pictures what else to say. Amazing low light performance, beats the nikkor hands down.

Name: Amazon Customer
Title: World's fastest zoom nears perfection
Reviews: The fastest zoom lens ever made, Canon and Nikon owners have had access for a while. As of July 2014, Pentax shooters can get one, too - which I did. And I am very, very happy about it. This lens will be on my camera probably 80% of the time.First, the bad news: 1) It's heavy, and mounted to my K-3, it's a beastly combo. I'll live with it. 2) I wish they could have engineered this quality into an 18-50 or thereabouts. (This is probably impossible...but then, this lens seems impossible.) Usually I can just get a little closer to the subject if needed, so it's not such a hardship. 3) It is prone to lens flare, so shots that include a bright sun can be challenging. This one is a bit irritating, but I have another lens I can use in such situations if need be. And after all, most of my work doesn't feature a mid-day sun. Because of these things, if I could grade it 4.5 instead of 5, I'd do that. But it's too good to rate a 4.Beyond that, all news is good! The image clarity from this lens is superb - near perfect at center, and very good even at the edges and corners. What's more, that statement holds true across the focal range, and at any aperture, even wide open. Beautifully crisp at 35mm, it's even better at 18 and, as you might expect, best around the middle of its range.Construction is very solid with both the focus and zoom rings moving smoothly and holding position once set. Autofocus can be fine-tuned manually without switching to manual mode, and the lens length never changes. (Focus and zoom actions happen entirely inside.) Nor does the outer ring rotate, making polarized filters easy to use.Vignetting and CA's are modest, and stopping down slightly will all but eliminate them. Barrel distortion and pincushion are to be expected with any zoom, but it's controlled and I'm sure a Pentax corrective profile will soon be available for Lightroom 5 users. (It's already there for Canon and Nikon versions.)While no lens is perfect, this one comes closer than any zoom I know of, and it's on par with the best primes in this focal range, making them redundant. Portraits, landscapes, street shooting - this is a versatile, very high quality lens.Sigma has come a long way in this business, and they've now asserted themselves as innovation and quality leaders. Yet somehow, they still price like a "value" player. I love this lens and I'm becoming a big Sigma fan, too.

Name: Daryl
Title: Nice lens
Reviews: Pic with nikon d3400. Left was just playing with lightroom and right is straight fr the camera.

Name: Nic
Title: GREAT FOR PHOTO, NOT NECESSARILY FOR VIDEO
Reviews: The picture quality is phenomenal and especially impressive in low-light (as many have mentioned).It performs superbly as three prime lenses in one.I took off a star because of its inability to auto-focus well on my 70D. The quality is still there, but the AF is not nearly as quiet as the Canon and it can skip frames while you're moving around when the camera is trying to auto-focus. It also lacks image stabilization. I did a comparison to the Canon 18-55 mm STM w/ IS lens that my 70D came with and when it comes to shooting video in motion, the Canon wins by a mile; not on picture sharpness or quality, but on the fact that you can actually watch the video without any skips or shaking.As far as bang for your buck, it's hard to beat the Sigma 18-35mm F1.8 HSM lens for photography, but if you're looking for a good lens for shooting video, this might not be for you.

Name: Jeffrey
Title: Autofocus issues.
Reviews: Possibly the worst autofocus of all time, but images are crisp and clear. I shoot on the Canon 7D, perhaps it is my own camera with issues, but my other lenses work fine.

Name: stevenj2
Title: Build quality good. Focus is the issue
Reviews: Large and heavy for APSC. Build quality good. Focus is the issue. Send mine today 9-14-16 to Sigma on Long Island with a Pentax body to calibrate.The only way to insure good focus is ..you should set up camera body to use back button focus. Look it uo if you did not know to D-Link shutter button to focus. Use live view plus back button focus ..after it locks focus you may like to shu live view off to check framing thru the viewfinder. Use this method anyrns gives you front or back focus problem. It takes the focus sensor out of the procesd.Hope you know thT DSLR have a separate focus sensor.Anyway Iike the Sigma but as I've spent too much for also Pentax 20-40 f/2.8-4.0 Limited plus a Pentax DA* 26-50 f/28 plus a Pentax 35 f/2.8 macro limited. which all feel different..the Sigma is secondary choice to use.

Name: Christopher R. Vickers
Title: The church had the worst lighting ever
Reviews: I was taking pics at a church during a wedding.The church had the worst lighting ever.I remembered that i purchased this lense a few days ago. I was desperate. My 24-70 and 28-75(Both 2.8) weren't cutting it. I then tried this lense. It did a very good job.However, you have to get somewhat close to the person your taking pictures of.Its a well built lense, but it is heavy.The F 1.8 makes a world pf difference

Name: Anonymous
Title: Purchased with ND filter - Perfect for film!
Reviews: Bought this lens mainly for videography. Being completely new to the game, when i tried to record in broad daylight I was dissappointed because I could not record at F/1.8 without raising the shutter. However I purchased an ND filter and problem solved! Loving it so far. Also great for photography!Here's a link to a video if you'd like to see test footage of the lens with ND filter!youtube[dot]com/watch?v=EsayGhcBnywAlso if you're curious the ND filter I purchased was: B+W 77mm ND 1.8-64X with Single Coating (106)

Name: Jinzei
Title: Legendary!
Reviews: This is an amazing lens like everyone says. Not really much to complain about optically, focuses really fast like a native lens. I had to get mine slight calibrated, though. My only major complaint is that it weighs like a tank. Prepare to get some nice bicep curls.

Name: efl
Title: Beautiful Portrait Glass At A Good Price Point
Reviews: For the price it is definitely on par with the Canon equivalents. I am using this on a 7d Mark II and my only complaint is the focus does hunt just a little longer than I would like but it's still pretty darn quick. Considering it's meant to be a superb portrait piece of glass - the little slower focus isn't a deal breaker. Bokeh is solid and the DOF at 1.8 is beautiful. Rent it first of course - but you'll love it.

Name: chris
Title: Just buy this now... If you have doubts, it does not disappoint.
Reviews: Fantastic Lens.Pros:Sturdy, heavy metal bodyVery fast- Large apertureVery sharp ImageGreat walk around lense for aps-c or micro4/3PriceCons:Heavy

Name: Chris
Title: You buy it.  You buy it now.
Reviews: Bought local since I was wary of Sigma lenses in case I had to return it. Best lens I've ever owned, simple as that. Incredibly sharp and fast. The focus is smooth. The build quality is like a tank... which is also its only downside, it's REALLY heavy. If you're not self conscious about toting around such a large lens, it makes for a perfect indoor low-light lens.

Name: David Wang
Title: Prime lens image quality for a zoom lens
Reviews: This lens is amazing, the quality you get for your money is unbelievable. For about 900$ you get to basically cram the Canon 20mm, 24mm, 28mm, and 35mm prime lenses into one convenient body (which would all together cost about 5000$). This lens is Canon L lens level image quality, often even surpassing the Canon lenses in terms of chromatic aberration, vignetting, color and sharpness. The bokeh is creamy and beautiful, and the f/1.8 capability adds great low-light versatility. The focusing is also fast and quiet, and you can tweak it with the Sigma USB dock if you so desire. Furthermore, the build quality is amazing and you can expect it to last you for a long time. The only downside I would say is the weight, it's quite hefty but what do you expect for zoom lens with a wide aperture.In general, this is a very versatile walk-around lenses that creates beautiful results. If you want Canon L lens quality without the price tag, this is the lens for you. It was money well spent.

Title: Just got it one week ago. It is very ...

Name: Bren
Title: Nice sharp lenes but heavy
Reviews: I must say this lenes is the whole package when it comes to sharpness and quality. I use it primarily for video on my 70D, The two problems I must say is it's pretty heavy alone and don't even mention adding other equipment. The other problem I encountered is the focus jumping in and out at times for no reason, I best suggest you MF for video. For pictures it's great especially in low light and dead sharp the auto focus is fast, smooth, and quiet. Other than that I would recommend this lens 100%

Name: Alexander Rau
Title: Great Lens. 3 Prime Lenses in one. Great focus Ring.
Reviews: This is the first time i leave a review for a product on Amazon. I found out about this lens by accident. I was looking for a good f2.8 zoom lens and read in all kinds of forums about f2.8 lenses from Sigma, Tamron and Canon.In one of the forums someone mentioned a 15-35mm f1.8 from Sigma and i though he might have mistaken and it was a f2.8 not a f1.8. But I gave it a try and did a search on Amazon for this lens and sure enough there it was.My biggest concern was the focus ring. My other Sigma (18-55 f2.8-3.5) has a very loose, short distance focus which makes it difficult to pull my own focus when I am filming. The local camera store did not have this lens in stock, so i could not try it out. Looking at some reviews and videos I gave it a try and ordered this lens.First impression:- Lens is build like a tank. No plastic crap. All metal. Very robust- Focus ring almost a half turn. With SOFT stop. No hard stop and loud click when you reach the end. I love the focus ring. Well done, Sigma- Zoom Ring the same, smooth and easy to find with your fingers.- F1.8 is great. Where can you find an 18mm lens with an f1.8?- This lens gives you 3 Prime lenses in one. 18mm, 24mm, 35mm. Saves you money.- Very close focus. I can get to an inch close to an object and still focus.i shot my last video for a client with it and loved the lens. Great for Video.Other thoughts. The lens is heavy. It was build to last and that is OK. I can feel the weight of the lens at the end of the day. Not a huge negative, because quality is heavy. My Tamron f2.8 is lighter, but the focus ring and build is not even close to the quality of this lens.This lens is cheap, compared to getting 3 canon prime lenses. Bonus is you don't have to swap lenses.With this lens and my Tamron 24-70mm f2,8 I can film everything. i basically only switch between these two lenses. My pack got lighter and I have space to take other things with me.

Name: Gatorowl
Title: Replaces Multiple Primes, But Does Have AF Issues Wide Open
Reviews: This is one of the sharpest lenses I have ever used. It's pointless to compare it with other zoom lenses. Rather, it competes with the better prime lenses. However, it is not perfect.My copy has AF issues. At apertures larger than f2.8 it is neither consistent nor accurate. The deviance from accuracy ranges from minor to quite substantial (i.e., noticeable at normal viewing size). I tested on both a D7100 and a D800E. The D800E was a bit better (when it missed, it didn't miss by as much or as often).Liveview focusing was far more accurate, and I could see how good the lens is at all aperture values (it's amazingly sharp at f1.8). No AF problems at smaller apertures (f2.8-f8). The lens truly sings at these aperture values. When in focus, the resolving power is amazing. Microcontrast is indeed lower at larger apertures. However, it was very difficult for me to detect any difference in detail resolved when stopped down. Contrast and color improved on stopping down (it really seemed to peak at f5.6), but I did not detect additional detail.The lens performs incredibly consistently across the entire zoom range. Edges really do not lose much sharpness compared to the center. Others have noted that the lens is strongest at distance at the wider end of the zoom, and stronger close up at the longer end. However, my testing was not sophisticated enough to detect such nuances. I suspect most would not be able to discern differences.Zooming and manual focusing rings are nicely damped. Definitely not too sticky or rigid as others have experienced.So, what to do about the flakey AF wide open? I'd love to deduct half a star. However, given that this zoom blows away all other lenses at f2.8 and smaller apertures--i.e., this is the best f2.8 zoom available for the D7100--, I consider the larger aperture values a bonus. I can shoot manual for critical situations requiring wide-open shooting, so I don't consider the AF issue major enough to deduct any stars. I also have hope that Sigma might address the AF issue in a future firmware release.All-in-all, this is an amazing lens. While the zoom range is a bit tight, it most definitely replaces prime lenses in its range.
